For once in a long time (that means it's rare) the movies guys down in southern California, have come up with something novel to entertain us with. This is a movie to just enjoy, get the popcorn and have fun.

reviews.review_title: To all attackers of this movie...
reviews.content: I didn't want comment this one at first until I saw the kinds of remarks people put towards the story.Yes, the plot is goofy, maybe silly, but it is not the flaw of the movie. I think it's meant to be that way, deliberately exaggerated nearly satirical description of paranoia people had developed in early 60's concerning communism, Cold War etc.In fact, until the moment the main character exits the shelter, it's a satire on the 60's, and from that point it turns into a satire on the 90's. You can feel a little nostalgia in the ways of Adam Webber and how he influences the people around him without himself turning into a bitter 90's man.This movie is watchable several times, has it's moments and is lighthearted, so I don't know what's the point finding plot-holes in it.

I'm glad I remembered this movie existed as I remember watching it many years ago and loving it. I thought of it again recently when I saw a photo of Brendan Fraser. It doesn't seem to be widely available to watch, especially not for free, so I rented it online. I'm so glad I did as I was reminded of how brilliant it really is and how much it makes me laugh. It's so entertaining to watch and Brendan Fraser plays the part perfectly. I don't think they could have cast anyone better for the role. The storyline is fantastic and such a great idea. This is definitely a favourite of mine.

I enjoyed this little movie.  The most entertaining part of the move was the part with Walken and Spacek underground with Adam.  It made me think of a simpler time when I was growing up in the 'burbs. The middle act was also entertaining when Walken and then Fraser venture into what they believe is the post-Apocalypse United States.   Spacek is also funny when she looks forward to getting her liquor supply restored.The final act of the movie is somewhat of a disappointment as it degenerates into standard romantic comedy formula. But all-in-all, I would recommend this movie for as an entertaining bit of fluff that is a very pleasant way to spend a couple of hours. 7/10

Calvin Webber is an inventor who has become wealthy and has taken to tinkering in his shed while his pregnant wife gets on with running her home. At the height of the Cuban missile crisis Calvin has built an underground bomb shelter with decades of supplies but it is a plane crash that he takes for a bomb that sees him and Helen flee underground. While the world moves on overhead, the Webbers are assumed dead in the crash while they actually try to raise their son Adam in their large shelter. Decades go by and young Adam has become a man by the time the shelter automatically opens. Calvin mistakes the night in the bad neighbourhood above him for a society in decay and returns full of fear. However a heart attack sees Adam forced to head to the surface.The plot suggests a comedy that will deliver comedy a la Enchino Man (albeit that not being a good thing in itself) but the delivery is much closer to a romantic comedy-drama. This mix is perhaps partly responsible for the film itself being all very so-so; amiable enough but nothing worth writing home about and likely to be forgotten not long after finishing watching it. This is not to say it is bad though because mostly it is a fairly inoffensive affair that fills the time. The plot is nonsense of course but underground it sort of works as it is in its own world. When Adam comes to the surface though it tries to be "real" but the fact that it is nonsense is clearer than ever, which is a problem since it also asks us to buy into Adam and Eve's relationship at this point  something I found hard to do. However it does provide amusement even if there are surprisingly few laughs bigger than a chuckle.The cast help it be better than it is (albeit only to a point). Fraser's boyish innocence works well in the title role. His material is weak but yet he goes with it and is good with it. Walken is mercifully restrained where he could easily have hammed it up in the caricature of himself which he does sometimes. His underplaying works well in the context. Spacek is not as good. It doesn't help that her character isn't that good but she doesn't do much with it either way. Silverstone is dumped with the "straight" role and has to convince in her growing relationship with Adam; she does it better than I expected but still isn't great, partly thanks to the material. Support from Foley and a few others is all well and good but mostly the film is best when Fraser, Walken or both are allowed to do their work.Even with them though this is amiable distraction at best. The comedy is soft and not particularly funny and the drama side not convincing at all as it is undermined by the silliness of the overall concept. It will pass the time but nothing more than that.
Absolutely loved this movie! The laughter this movie bring my family will make it a classic we will never refuse to watch. The cast alone is amazing and unforgettable.

The film begins during the Cuban Missile Crisis in the early 1960s. A paranoid family mistakenly believes that a nuclear war has taken place and they go into their underground bomb shelter for refuge. Unfortunately, they didn't know that things did blow over and everyone was fine. As a result, they waited for years until they ultimately left their shelter to see the outside world. The husband (Christopher Walken) sees a bunch of freaky-dressed people and assumes some sort of horrible post-apocalyptic society has taken hold...and rushes back to the shelter. The son, Adam(Brendan Fraser), has never seen the outside world and he goes much further than his father...exploring the world outside. Unfortunately, he's completely out of place here and is incredibly naive. When he tries to sell his baseball cards for cash, a jerk tries to swindle him. But one of his employees, Eve (Alicia Silverstone), sees this and stops the transaction...and is promptly fired. Now, with a new friend, Adam explores the world and she helps him look for a wife. What's next? See the film.If you are looking for a laugh out loud movie, this probably isn't it. Instead, it's a gentle, sweet romance...and most enjoyable. A truly unique story well worth seeing.

Yeah, this is pretty good-kinda equal parts 'Pleasantville', 'Back to the Future' and 'Big'. I really like Brendan Fraser as an actor, its too bad that this didn't do that well for him considering its harmless fun, and done with some heart.Silverstone as an actress is strictly average-but the camera loves her and what the hey-she's only 24 or so, she's more someone who was brought up early and became famous before knowing what she was doing before a camera.This movie sometimes plays like an extended sit-com, more or less Happy Days level in spots-but if you forgive the stereotyped cartoony characters Spacek, Schiavelli and Walken have to play, and just go with it-you will enjoy.The actors are good and its not bad.**1/2 outta ****, pretty decent time-killer, nothing great.

This movie is a delight and if anyone tells you differently it's because they have no joy in their lives. I love a fish out of water story, as well wholesome characters. Brendan Fraser plays this so well and Alicia Silverstone is like a jaded, slightly grown up Cher Horowitz. Adam is the character that brings people back to simpler times. His thirst to learn about the world is infectious, sort of like seeing the world through a child's eyes. If you're looking for a transcendent experience, this may not be it. But it is fun and very worth the time if you ask me. Get out your warm Dr. Pepper and 30 years worth of rations and enjoy.

This is a superbly funny and original comedy, very well made and thoroughly entertaining. Christopher Walken brings his kooky and strange presence to the role of the father whilst Sissy Spacek descends dizzily into an alcoholic haze - but after living in an underground fallout shelter for most of her life who could blame her?. Brendan Fraser has been brought up with a 60's lifestyle for 35 years and suddenly finds himself in the virtually alien civilisation of the late 90's. The script is very well written and brings many laugh out loud moments. The use of colour in the production design is exceptional, the music evocative but never overwhelming. Above all Brendan Fraser is an absolute delight and joy to watch, making the very most of the comic potential in his role.

I finished this film, thinking, "That was pretty funny." The writing is meant to make us all laugh and succeeds; never in my life have I laughed so hard.Unfairly dismissed by some, this is a funny comedy. The movie is very light-hearted and it isn't complex at all. All the characters struggle against a system that has perpetuated many falsehoods. This is one of those movies that had bad timing when it came to its release. I am not saying the film is a classic, but it was good enough. A good one from the 1990s. It's one of those films for which I could guess the plot exactly before I saw it. Fraser is a unique presence in American cinema and hopefully he will do more of these types of films. I give it 7/10.

This is one of those gems which I have thoroughly enjoyed watching multiple times. You need to see it a few times to be able to fully appreciate all the nuanced looks (for example, when Sissy Spacek "watches" Christopher Walken, or Alicia Silverstone watches Brendan Fraser at times.) The 50's/early 60's styling is spot on, and all the character actors add wonderful spice. We just brought it over to a friends' home to watch it on their new very large television, and noticed even more details that we have missed in the past. The plot, while somewhat predictable as a romantic comedy, also leaves enough room for both main characters (Adam and Eve!) to grow as people, which I very much appreciate. Brendan Fraser, Alicia Silverstone and the rest of the actors were well cast, and fit the parts as if they were born to them. The writing and pacing is tight, which is another reason to watch it more than once. There are quite a few foreshadowing references/events which you will definitely miss the first time. I enjoy it more each time I see it. There are very few movies that I can say that about. You will also laugh out loud more than once.If you enjoy romantic comedies with great "unsaid lines" (said with just a glance,) coupled with a crazy sounding premise that works (supported by excellent cast, writing, set dressing and pacing) then you will be glad that you watched this movie. I hope that you enjoy it as much as I do. Again and again!

reviews.review_title: Blast Turns Into A Dud With More Bias
reviews.content: Usually I am sucker for time-travel films, loving most of them....but not this yet-another subtle anti-religion propaganda nonsense. In this film, Christopher Walken plays a father ("Calvin Webber") who espouses wholesome family values and is shown as a religious man. So this man who - gasp - says grace at meals - is pictured as a complete lunatic. What else? Is there no end to the cheap shots by these atheists who dominate the film world?I did enjoy the first third of this movie but when Brendan Fraser's lead character, "Adam Webber" went "up' to the existing world, the movie just fades into another "fish out of water" film, which has been used many times in many different circumstances.This was no "blast" from the past. There are too many other far-better time-travel flicks than this one.

This film never made it to the big screen in Sweden. It might be the kind of film that I would prefer to see on video, but as it turned out, I didn't have a choice. Anyway - this is a very good film. Not only is it funny, it is an intelligent kind of fun - just look at Walken (who performs, like he always does, splendidly) and his obsessiveness, or the mother (Spacek) who is clearly going bonkers (and becoming an alcoholic) in the shelter. Or the nutty owner of the bar ("Leave my elevator alone!"). I even thought Silverstone's character was fairly good, though the twists of the plot forced her to become unnecessarily hostile in the bar scenes. Imagine how a white person who had never actually seen a colored person (or vice versa, for that matter), only heard about "them" would react. That is REALLY funny.What bothers me is the ease with which Eve falls for this guy. The way he acts, talks and dresses would be more than enough to put her off completely - I for one would have called some authority a lot sooner...But, it is a comedy, and a romantic one at that, so let's not bother about scientific or psychological facts and theories. It's entertainment, and I think it works well.

reviews.review_title: An amusing comedy that chose safety over hilarity
reviews.content: "Blast from the Past" is pleasant and amusing, while delivering an interesting commentary on social values and the deterioration of manners, education and other aspects of society. Brendan Fraser is perfect as Adam, a Renaissance man with superb theoretical social skills but inexperience, so initially comes off as nothing more than a likable doofus, but gradually grows into the gentleman he was trained to become. His character's innocence, naïveté and tendency to view issues as B&W dichotomies represent society's world view in the 1950s and 1960s. Christopher Walken delivers an unusually understated performance and steals the film in the very last scene. Alicia Silverstone does as well as can be expected with the material she was given, but her Eve character is underdeveloped. She seems like an okay sort of girl next door, but doesn't offer enough to justify Adam's fascination with her to the exclusion of several other girls who superficially seem more obvious choices. She has a competing love interest in Cliff, but it never seems clear why she loved him before and doesn't love him now but is still a bit fixated on him. The relationship seems a bit contrived. He's there when the plot needs a low point for Adam but conveniently absent at other times. And it doesn't make much sense that alpha male Cliff would have moved in with her rather than inviting her to move in with him, or that he wouldn't park in front of her house. Eve's entire character also seems contrived. She doesn't seem the type who would frequent the trendy nightclub they visit or to have a gay roommate. While the film is amusing, it falls short of hilarious. Much of the humor is fairly subtle. Many jokes and gags require lengthy setups. The writers don't fully utilize all of the comic tools in their arsenal. There aren't many sight gags other than Adam's unstylish suit. Recurring and 1-2-3 gags aren't used very effectively. The baseball cards and baseball game don't escalate the humor. There are a few verbal gags and double entendres, such as gay/happy, but there's room for many more. The foreground and background aren't used effectively. At one point Eve and her gay roommate Troy enter a porn shop looking for Adam. They jump up and down on the floor, to determine if there's a basement, but it's done very seriously. Cut twice to a customer clutching an armload of VHS tapes and backing away as if they are weird. The Pakistani shop owner approaches, wearing a lot of gold jewelry in what may or may not have been intended as a politically incorrect commentary on the influence of immigrants growing rich by peddling porn. They have an exchange that includes one of the best jokes in the movie, then ask about a rear entrance. Including the setup, the scene lasts for about eighty seconds. It could have been shortened by showing the customer in the background instead of in separate shots. The customer is overweight and looks a bit nerdish or borderline weird. There are a number of things they could have done to make the scene funnier. He could have dropped a tape at Eve's feet and she could have picked it up for him only to have him deny it was his. He could have hurriedly replaced a movie and asked the shopkeeper if he carries any historical documentaries. He could have approached Eve and asked her if she was Dixie Normous, the famous porn star, and asked if she would autograph the box for him. Troy does a little dance step in an effort to see if the floor sounds hollow. He could have gotten on his knees and put his ear to the floor. That could have led to a sight gag and physical comedy. Except for the one joke, which was admittedly one of the best in the movie, the setting could have been changed to a barbershop or grocery store. They didn't push the envelope or try to squeeze every laugh they could out of the scene. In part, they seem to have tried to be inoffensive, going as far as to blur the images of bare breasts on the video jackets, possibly trying to maintain the tone and sensitivities of the 1950s and 1960s. For their efforts, the film still got a PG-13 rating. But what's the point? Viewers who would be most likely to appreciate the references to manners, mores and cultural references of that period would have been in their forties or fifties in 1999 when the film was released. Much of the humor would have made no sense to younger viewers. Some aspects of the movie are simply not funny. A character becomes alcoholic. Another character goes stir-crazy. A plane crashes in a residential neighborhood. While they take pains to suggest there were no casualties, including having the plane go vertical before nosediving, plane crashes simply aren't funny. Consequently, the film has an uneven tone. But the trade-off is a cinematic billet doux to a lost age of innocence.
Love this movie since I saw it first. Funny and definitely has a message about society.

reviews.review_title: The most poignant culture criticism of my lifetime
reviews.content: No matter how unhappy people are in modern times, no matter how twisted and perverted our culture becomes, we are constantly reminded that no matter how bad things are - the past was worse. This is an extremely subversive movie, and why few will directly state why they dislike this film - it is the visceral reaction that they get from an inability to wholly defend the present and its many dysfunctions. One could right a radical treatise on the decadence and corruption of modernity based on this film alone. It touches on nearly every aspect of life, all carefully and neatly presented as harmless comedy. A truly brilliant film, and one that likely could never be produced today, in this era of hyper political persecution.

reviews.review_title: Beautifully innocent from start to finish
reviews.content: In this romantic charmer, Brendan Fraser displays more than ever that he is highly underrated. His Adam's innocence and kindness are believable and not cliche. His (and Christopher Walken's and Dave Foley's) understanding of the subtle humor carries the film.It might be a perfect film if someone other than Alicia Silverstone was cast as the leading lady. Silverstone doesn't seem to understand that Eve can be sarcastic and cynical without being downright mean. She is of the false notion that making faces, grimacing and scowling substitute for portrayal of a complex role.Perhaps it's a matter of poor characterization on the writer's part, but the confusing Eve just left me mad - even yelling at the screen: she can't decide what she wants, isn't honest to Adam, and plays that "cruel to be kind" style of flirting. Her jealousy and cattiness is cliche, and so "movie and magazine stereotypical." (i.e., getting jealous of the two blondes swing dancing with style with Adam, furious that Adam went home with Sophia, even though Eve left the night club without Adam.)I can get past that, though, because every other character is carried out confidently and wisely by the rest of the cast. It moves along nicely with surprising observations the whole way.Four subtly hilarious moments: 1. Adam: "Driver! Stop the bus! Stop the bus immediately!" 2. Bellhop: "Dial 9 to get out." Adam: "Of what?" 3. Adam: (sincerely, whenever he leaves one's presence) "May I be excused?" 4. Adam: (confused after Eve calls someone a Dickhead, he falls against a wall in a confused state) "I'm just trying to picture..."I just thought this was a truly sweet film - the polite, respectful, innocent man is a dream come true. If only I could meet someone who's been underground for 35 years, purely unjaded by the world, and as honest as Adam! Then again, this is a movie.

reviews.review_title: Starts off promisingly but by the end, it's just a typically average romance flick.
reviews.content: The premise of this movie, though far-fetched, is really quite clever. Then the film becomes a typical, run of the mill romance, with Brendan Frasier acting like a goofy little boy and Alicia Silverstone giving a terrible performance.The year is 1962, and Calvin Webber (Christopher Walken) has secretly been building a huge underground bomb shelter stocked with food and all the needs for his wife Helen (Sissy Spacek) and their soon to be son Adam (Brendan Frasier). Calvin thinks the Cold War has started when a fire hits their house and they go underground. To avoid nuclear fallout, the time lock doesn't let them out for 35 years. In this time Helen has the baby, and they try to live normal lives. Meanwhile up above them, their house was demolished and their neighborhood made into a collection of porno and liquor stores. When the time lock goes off, Adam is sent up to get supplies for the family, and to meet a woman. He ends up meeting Eve (Alicia Silverstone), who he falls for. She works for him driving him around and helping him sell his father's very rare baseball cards. Bad romance and acting ensues from here.The first 40 minutes or so are really amusing. Life in the fallout shelter is interesting to watch, and Christopher Walken is a great opening lead actor. The film then switches away from him to Brendan Frasier, and it's actually still good then too. The fish out of water comedy is actually funny, and Brendan's goofy over the top performance works well. But, when Alicia Silverstone comes into the picture, this falls apart. She is absolutely terrible in this, and she has awful dialogue too, making this a double whammy for her role. The romantic scenes are really corny, and the musical score only makes it worse. By the end, this is no more than your average romance flick, and maybe even worse than the typical romance films in some ways, but the opening and some moments of well done humor keep this movie (barely) afloat.My rating: ** 1/2 out of ****. 112 mins. PG-13 for language.

This film did surprisingly poor business, not so much because it's bad, but because it turns out to be the type of slight picture that doesn't generate "Must-See" word of mouth, yet eventually finds a home on the small screen."Blast From the Past" is able to overcome a rather listless first 20 minutes or so, in which it methodically and somewhat mechanically lays the groundwork for its stockpile of running jokes; and emerges as an agreeable, if modest comedy that supplies at least a dozen big laughs.Hugh Wilson is a rather hit-or-miss director, whose films always seem to be stretched too thin (like "Guarding Tess"). Too often, there just doesn't seem to be enough going on, and he can stubbornly persist with secondary material that just isn't funny - like the running gag about the religious cult that forms around Fraser when he first comes up from underground. Every once in a while, however, Wilson hits his stride and finds just the right touch - as in the moment where it suddenly dawns on Dave Foley's bitchy gay best friend that good manners like Fraser's are a show of respect for those in his company, not a sign of superiority.It's great to see Christopher Walken in a non-villainous role, playing the square, paranoid scientist father, and looking quite a bit like Michael Douglas' vigilante in "Falling Down". There's always been a hint of amusement in even his vilest bad guy portrayals, and here he shows a nice flair for comedy. (As he did when he guest-hosted on "SNL", come to think of it.) As the naive, hilariously polite innocent, Fraser gets all the laugh-out-loud lines ("DRIVER, PLEASE STOP THE BUS!"); and Silverstone is very appealing in her melt-away cute way, as the cynical but vulnerable 90's chick. She does a good job varying her bewildered "What planet are you from?" reactions to Fraser's bizarre behaviour. The two have a nice chemistry together.There's an illogical decision by Silverstone's character near the end which was not believable for a second, but this is generally a funny movie with a measure of charm.

reviews.review_title: some derivative fun for baby boomers
reviews.content: Brendan Fraser is a "Blast from the Past" in this 1999 film also starring Christopher Walken, Sissy Spacek, Alicia Silverstone, and Dave Foley.Walken and Spacek are Calvin and Helen. Calvin has worked assiduously over years to prepare for the anticipated nuclear holocaust - he has recreated his home underground, and supplied the family with enough food and necessities to last 30+ years. During the Cuban missile crisis, Calvin and his pregnant wife rush into the shelter. Sure enough, there's a huge blast. It's not the nuclear disaster Calvin thinks it is - it's a plane that crashes on his property and blows up.Calvin and Helen stay where they are, and Helen gives birth to baby Adam. Adam knows The Honeymooners and Perry Como records; he is home-schooled by his dad while his frustrated mother is boozing it up in the kitchen.When he's 35, Adam goes out into the world because it's now safe. He goes up in the elevator and comes out onto a building holding a bunch of homeless people, as the property has changed hands a couple of times since the house was decimated. One of the homeless men thinks he's Jesus.Out in the world, Adam meets the adorable Eve (Silverstone) who is totally '90s, as well as her gay friend Troy (Foley), and the cultures clash. And one other thing - in Eve, Adam has discovered woman.This is a cute comedy with lots of charm and great casting. Spacek and Walken as a couple - inspired, and Fraser is perfect as a happy, naive youth out in the world for the first time. Alicia Silverstone is delightful, and her reactions during the scene in which Adam tells her his real background are a riot. You can just see the wheels of panic.There isn't anything particularly new or fresh about this film, though it's fun. Characters have often wound up in other eras or on other planets. However, it is very pleasant with a good soundtrack, and a film that will appeal especially to those of us who well remember fallout shelters, the threat of Communism, and President Kennedy on TV talking about the Cuban missile crisis.

This movie is fun. Fun in the late 90s sense where you can have a ridiculous concept and go with it. It's the same type of humor as "The Wedding Singer" and the same buoyant energy. Thanks to a really committed Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek as doting parents of a different era.I love this movie for its non-cynical approach to making a movie. Hugh Wilson relies heavily on the two leads chemistry AND good-nature to carry us through. And I enjoyed the cultural evolution, or in this case de-evolution of humanity. A kind way to say we've lost our manners and civility.What would you take from this movie? Absolutely nothing. Maybe that you should be kinder to people. And that manners count. And that, when put into a vacuum and later exhumed from a different generation, we'd see how much we'd degenerated in our treatment of each other.To me, it's just fun. I think it defines the late 1990 era romantic comedy movies.

Blast From The Past is a very silly movie but very funny.Brendan Fraser plays the main character brilliantly with an innocent deadpan style.Not many laughs at the start while the story evolves but soon it's a laugh out loud movie.Great characters and a good family movie.There are plenty of holes in the story but it doesn't matter as it doesn't pretend to be anything but pure fictitious escapism filled with laughs.The only criticism is the last 15 minutes or so where the laughs dried up to wrap up the movie.

Take a worn out plot, and actors who really sell their parts and what do you have?  You have "Blast From The Past", a surprisingly funny and clever little movie starring Brendan Frasier and Alicia Silverstone.Brendan Frasier was truly the only choice for the part of Adam, a 35 year old man who has lived his entire life in a fallout shelter his parents moved into during the Cuban missile crisis. When the locks finally open and supplies are running low, young Adam is sent into the world with baseball cards, $3000 cash and "worthless" stocks from AT&T, IBM and others.  His blank look and goofy expressions are perfect, and he plays the part with so much enthusiasm that its hard not to like it.Alicia Silverstone gives her best performance to date, as (get this) Eve, the girl Adam (see I told you it was goofy) falls in love with.  She's your typical 90's girl.  Cynical, worldly and hopelessly in love with Adam. She too is so into her part and sells it so well, you have to enjoy it.  This was a wonderful role at a time when she had basically been forgotten. Welcome back Alicia, now show us you can be this good consistanly.
The most pleasant surprise in this movie is Dave Foley as Troy, Eve's gay roommate (yes, Adam thinks he's just happy).  As good as he is in "News Radio", he turns it up a notch here and delivers the funniest characterization I've seen him do yet."Blast From The Past" shows that if you have enough talent, you can carry a mediocre script into a wonderfully enjoyable movie.3 out of 4

reviews.review_title: Some things never change - and not always a bad thing
reviews.content: Rom-Coms such as Blast from the Past are a peculiar breed of film – they divide opinion unlike any other genre, and also, unlike other genres, seem to have little success with either the critics or the Academy but are cash cows at the box office. They are simple films, inoffensive and entertaining but usually almost instantly forgettable. It takes something special, different or unique to really make a rom-com stand out from the pack.Blast from the Past does have such a quality, in that its' plot is slightly different – Adam (Brendan Fraser) has spent his entire life in a fallout shelter (for reasons too long-winded to bother going into now) and emerges 35 years later to find a drastically changed world from that which his father (Christopher Walken) has taught him about. He must learn about this new world quickly with the help of his new friend Eve (Alicia Silverstone). Eve is wary at first of this strange man with impeccable manners and an unbelievably naïve view of the world. As they grow closer.well you can fill in the rest from there. Even the character names give the plot away! Though the plot itself is pretty predictable, the story of this 35-year-old guy approaching the world with the open-eyed wonder of a child is quite refreshing, and calls to mind a time when life was simpler. Brendan Fraser manages to capture this fresh-faced wonder without ever being too cringing. However, Alicia Silverstone's handling of her character's inevitable transition from being sceptical to falling in love does not ring totally true. She is adequate without being outstanding. Dave Foley is the beautiful girl's gay friend Troy – after all, every beautiful girl has a gay friend, or at least that's what these rom-coms would have us believe! Maybe it is so that there is another lead male that we can like without him ever being any kind of a threat to the leading man? Whatever it is, the situation does lead to some genuinely funny scenes. Further, it could have been quite easy to go way over the top with both the goofy comedy and slushy sentiment, and fortunately manages to avoid that fate on both counts.Also, a review of Blast from the Past would not be complete without mention of the music – filled with classic 50s and 60s swing music as well as more modern stuff (watch out for Troy teaching Adam the YMCA dance) and a terrific scene in a swing club, with great swing dancing and real toe-tapping music supplied by the Flying Neutrinos and the Cherry Popping' Daddies. The scene is almost worth the purchase of the DVD on its own – if you like that kind of thing.The film is the DVD equivalent of a comfort blanket, a nice simple film, easily enjoyable and good fun.

reviews.review_title: A hugely entertaining and touching comedy.
reviews.content: Hugh Wilson has directed a touching, funny and insightful comedy. Christoper Walken and Sissy Spacek portray a typical Californian suburban couple. It is 1962 at the height of the Cuban missile crisis. Walken has built an elaborate fallout shelter to sustain his family for 35 years in the event of a nuclear war. He and his wife mistakenly believe the war has begun when a plane crashes into their house. They lock the shelter and begin their 35 years underground. A little boy is born to them shortly thereafter, and he is raised in this insulated environment for the next 35 years.The passage of time in the shelter details the raising of their son who matures as the full grown Brendan Fraser. When the time arrives for them emerge (the present day) they send Fraser out into the world they believe has been adversely affected by the nuclear holocaust. Fraser meets Alicia Silverstone, a young Valley Girl who works in a baseball card store. Of course, she takes Fraser under her wing and the expected "fish out of water" situations develop. The romantic ins and outs of the second half of the film are quite predictable, but Fraser and Silverstone are so irresistibly charming that they overcome this easily. In a fantastic scene where Fraser does a dynamite 40's dance with two lovelies in a club, Silverstone realizes her true feelings towards him. By the way, Fraser does all his own dancing.This brief overview cannot even attempt to convey the magical synergy between the characters. Spacek and Walken are wonderful playing against type in roles so different from the serious parts we are used to seeing them in. Dave Foley is also effective as the platonic friend of Silverstone. Fraser and Silverstone beautifully portray the warmth and romance of the growing affection between their characters.Last but not least, some mention must be made of the stupendous soundtrack. Music is used to great effect from beginning to end. The song hits of the various decades will have you tapping your toes and running to the store to buy the CD. The use of surround sound is also quite effective in the musical sequences and in use of both subtle and explosive sound effects.Wilson, director of "First Wives Club", has another entertaining comedy to add to his credits. Don't miss it!

reviews.review_title: Boy, if there ever was a female wish fulfillment movie...
reviews.content: This is a neatly wrapped comedy that delivers enjoyment to every gender, age and orientation. BUT. As a heterosexual woman, and after the 10th time watching this, I finally realized that they are fanservicing *me*. Think about it: a man with a perfect body and a perfect soul, a lily-white-pure, tall, shapely, and ridiculously handsome, unspoiled, highly intelligent, exceedingly kind and thoughtful, very very wealthy young man, who happens to be an expert in martial arts and ballroom dancing and many languages... falls madly in love with you, a regular cute-ish girl from Pasadena who can't keep a job and always falls for the wrong guy.I mean, come on now.Well, at least they did it a lot better than Twilight. LOL

Once in a while a movie comes along that inspires you to think about the world around you and what it all means to be here.  This is one of those movies.  Here is a guy (played by Brendan Frasier) who in Jungian typology is the ultimate INFP, someone with the gentlest ideals and disposition, who enters a world of chaos and cynicism, yet remains kind and sunny.  It's a beautiful film for many reasons, the romance, the idealism, the humour, the contrasts.  For a moment we can forget about the internal or external battles of good vs evil typical of most Hollywood movies.  This is simply the story of a good person, someone we can all aspire to be like, in an unusual set of circumstances.  The premise of this movie is original, believable, and best of all a pleasure to watch.  It is brilliant beyond words.  I sincerely hope to find other movies by the same screenwriters (Bill Kelly & Hugh Wilson) that make me think and feel this way.

reviews.review_title: Brendan and Alicia have great chemistry.
reviews.content: Brendan and Alicia have great chemistry. Neither of them have been given credit for being very fine actors, especially Brendan.  My vote for best performance, though, would have to go to Sissy Spacek.  I've never liked her, but I LOVED her in this film.  As for the premise of the movie -- Hey, it could happen!

reviews.review_title: It really shouldn't work...and nearly doesn't
reviews.content: Out of an outlandish, crackpot plot comes some very dear moments, laugh-out-loud scenes and a sweet performance by Brenden Fraser. The highly-concocted scenario, concerning a 35-year-old man--having spent his life in a fallout shelter--entering modern society for the first time and falling in love, is so ridiculous on every level that the initial set-up is naturally full of groaners (especially with mom Sissy Spacek climbing down into the shelter with her pot-roast and oven mitts). But the film works hard to win its audience over and, with Fraser's performance as Adam so dead-on, it nearly succeeds. Alicia Silverstone is adorable as Eve (please!), yet her character doesn't make any sense (her erratic behavior would certainly scare any man away). The fake-nostalgia is thick enough to choke on, but any contemporary movie that plugs Perry Como so insistently can't be all bad... ** from ****

reviews.review_title: Retro romantic comedy full of holes
reviews.content: Blast from the Past is a romantic comedy with a silly title and a silly plot, but I don't feel cheated because it has pace and made me smile. The silly plot goes like this - SPOILERS AHEAD - it's the time of the Cuba crisis, Pres. Kennedy is on TV and Dad Webber (Christopher Walken) decides to move himself and mother-to-be Helen (Sissy Spacek) to his underground fallout shelter, which turns out to be something like Fort Knox stocked with food and supplies enough for a medium-sized country. For no reason that I can see, a jet fighter on a survey mission (over Cuba ?) crashes on the Weber's house (in Los Angeles huh? ) convincing Dad that nuclear WWIII has started. So what more natural than that he locks himself with Helen about-to-deliver into the shelter by activating a 35-year time lock ?To help us swallow this scenario which will lead to their newborn son Adam (Brendan Fraser) growing up for 35 years with only his parents' tutelage in 1960s values, the scriptwriters helpfully explain some practical matters like the septic tank, but miss many others such as where does the electric power come from and why do they have unlimited technical equipment but no radio?Thankfully the 35 years go by fairly quickly (for us), the door lock goes "click" and now our family can emerge. Whoops - the reason given for staying underground is that "the nuclear radiation has a half-life of 35 years" so declaring an all-clear seems premature. Anyway Dad does go upside and basically misunderstands everything he sees in the sleazy LA district that has developed where the Webber house used to stand. He returns convinced that radiation has caused a race of mutant humans to evolve. Hellooooo!Now it is son Adam's turn to venture into today's world, and what has happened so far is best forgotten as being a clumsy set-up for the boy-meets-girl formulaic comedy that follows. I find that hardly worth describing, it has stereotypical characters and the girl that Adam meets is named Eve (played by Alicia Silverstone who is sour when she should be sweet and never gets sweet at all). After a bit of chasing,  a bit of Eve getting bitchy about Adam being popular with girls at a nightclub, one of whom really is sweet, a bit of Adam punching a rival boyfriend, a bit of Adam being gentlemanly to the first black person he meets, an ongoing joke with a gay friend who "understands" Eve (but thankfully does not ham up his stereotype), it is time for Adam and Eve to ride off together into the sunset - or, in this case, to gently ease his parents into the present, non-atom-blasted reality. Why that should be such a problem, and why a goofy religious fanatic needs to be kept on hand after he has delivered a few gags, I can't tell you. The movie just seemed to run out into the sand at that juncture.But I am not complaining, nor do I feel the need to expose this good-hearted comedy to probing sociological analysis nor poke more holes in it. For similar movie-meat cooked much more profoundly, watch instead Pleasantville, which I have also reviewed. BTW is the Viet Nam debacle still such a catharsis in the US/Hollywood psyche that filmmakers turn to the Cuban missile crisis almost as light relief ? After all, no one feels that as dangerous now and we won it, didn't we ?

reviews.review_title: Sort of wasted potential but still entertaining enough.
reviews.content: The movie has a good comical premise; A well educated but without any life-experience adult, who has lived all is life in fallout shelter, goes out, into the big world for the first time in 35 years. Having grown up in a '60's environment, he of course also runs into some big differences in language and morals. It's a real good comical premise to create a fun movie with. For most part "Blast from the Past" is also a fun movie but not halve as good and entertaining as it could had been if it had used a different approach.The movie begins as a comedy almost entirely set in the inside of a fallout shelter, that looks almost exactly like a real house and also has its own supermarket and fishing-pool. The main characters of the movie are being played by Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek. However the second halve of the movie entirely focuses on the 'son', played by Brendan Fraser, in the big wide world, with Alicia Silverstone as his love interest. It makes the movie so that it can be divided into two separate parts. It does make the movie disjointed and also not the best to watch comedy around.The movie its premise does offer the movie plenty of comical opportunities. At first it handles this well and it provide the movie with some of its best and most fun moments, when the Brendan Fraser sees the 'world' and everything that is in it for the first time. Yet later on the movie lays its emphasis entirely on the love-story, which does makes this movie nothing more than just another typical and also predictable genre movie. A waste of the good comical potential this movie its premise offered.The acting is still top-class. Brendan Fraser is actually a real great comical actor that can make his character likable as well as believable, without ever going too over-the-top with it. But yes, it's definitely true that the best roles of the movie are being played by Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek. They are great actors and play their characters subtly hilarious. The movie is filled with some good written comical characters and some good lines to let the fine actors deliver.It's a movie with a couple of hilarious moments and also some great lines but its romantic-comedy approach doesn't really make this movie as original and hilarious as it could had been.6/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

reviews.review_title: A sleeper hit - clever, funny and moving
reviews.content: This movie is a real sleeper - or at least it was for me. I have to say, I didn't really expect much from it... a quirky romantic comedy on a rather goofy sounding premise starring Alicia Silverstone (who didn't exactly distinguish herself in Excess Baggage). But this movie just blew me away. I loved it. I laughed (a lot), I cried (more than once)... definitely one of the year's best for me! Christopher Walken has always been one of my favourite actors, and he turns in a fine performance here as the proud and slightly deluded father intent on protecting his family. But he couldn't have carried the movie on his own. Of course it certainly helps that the script is strong and the direction sure... firmly founded in historical and cultural awareness and never for a moment losing sight of the humanity of the characters. But then almost all the performances are strong. Veteran Sissy Spacek as the mother is as good as you'd expect from her illustrious career. Brendan Fraser continues to go up in my estimation - he has the most difficult role of all, needing to be both absurd and heroic, and to avoid falling into the bathetic or saccharine... and I felt he succeeded admirably. Then Alicia Silverstone... well, I still have slightly mixed feelings about her (perhaps Clueless raised too many wrong expectations)... but really she brings a liveliness and warmth to her role here, and turns in a functional and endearing performance. And Dave Foley as her 'special best friend' Troy definitely deserves a mention of his own... he makes a major contribution. I'd recommend this movie to just about anyone... or at least anyone who finds humour, intelligence and humanity in a movie sufficient.

reviews.review_title: Poisonous gas in the adult bookstore!
reviews.content: When I walked out of the theater after watching this movie I was just elated. Something about this movie has the ability to make me feel great. I love the movie's idealism, its innocence. From its goofy beginning to the ending credits with Randy Newman singing. Yes, I am a 21-year-old college male and yes, most of my friends make fun of me for loving/owning this movie, but I don't care! Hugh Wilson has come a long way since "Police Academy"! (And thank goodness!) After spending his whole life in a bomb shelter with his "Leave it to Beaver" parents we watch as Adam (a 30+ year-old man) sees the world for the first time. He's a big, very-likable child who assumes that everybody shares his love of Perry Como. I must say, though, that the highlight of this movie for me had to be Dave Foley (from "Kids in the Hall" fame). If for nothing else, watch it for him. I also found him to be one of the most likable screen characters in recent memory.I would say if you loved watching Dave Foley in "NewsRadio," then this is a must-see. It's hard to say just what makes this movie's naivete so contagious, but it works. It's far-fetched, it's cheesy, it's idealistic. It always has this goofy grin on its face that forces the viewer to just surrender and smile along with it.

reviews.review_title: Like in many movies, the children here have a lesson for the adults.
reviews.content: I'm not surprised there are negative reviews of this movie that don't discuss this movies politics. I am surprised there are 199 reviews of this movie (200 now), and not a single review discusses politics.Director Hugh Wilson (Police Academy) seems to be to making a political or social point here. The romance/comedy between Adam (Brandan Frasier) and Eve (Alicia Silverston) seems an incidental add-on. So much care and attention to detail went into creating the look and feel of 1960 America, the whole point of the movie must be to contrast that time with today. I don't buy the Webber family going down into their elaborate back yard shelter in 1960 and then returned to the surface in 1999, as simply a vehicle for this romance comedy.The Webbers are a nice family if not perfect. Mr Webber dresses and acts a lot like Michael Douglas in the movie 'Falling Down'. During a period of tension during the cold war, while the Webber family is in their bomb shelter - a plane crashes in the families yard - they assume nuclear war. They educate and train their only child Adam underground as best they can inside the bomb shelter. Time passes. Mr Webber sends his son Adam, 35 now, above ground for the first time to get supplies for the family. Telling him, "be careful for mutants, son". When Adam gets up top, he mistakes half the people he meets for mutants (transsexuals, punk rockers, etc).Adam does meet Eve, falling in love with her. First, prudently asking if she's a mutant or not. The characters in the film are all likable - the Webber family, and Eve, playing a redemptive role here, and Eves' friend Troy - as is the movie itself likable.As is the case in many movies, the child here, Adam (who's only ever meet 2 people in his entire life, his mom and dad), has a lesson for the adults. Adam saying, "Manners, are just a way for us to show other people we care about them". Later adding, "A 'gentleman' is, someone who always tries to make sure people around him or her are as comfortable as possible." Eve asks about Adam, "Where do you think he got all that information?" Eves' friend replies, "From the oddest place - his parents."

During the Cuban Missle Crisis, Calvin, an eccentric scientist(Walken) decides that in order to survive a nuclear bomb he must take shelter in a bunker. Christopher Walken is the king of quirky and is a perfect choice to play this odd character. The only problem with him is he doesn't have enough screentime.
Surviving nuclear war is something Calvin has thought about and he has built a fallout shelter; that is almost like a house and has enough supplies to last three people 35 years. The third person being the son he and his wife are expecting. They're son, Adam(Fraser), is born in the shelter and he is taught much in the fields of academics, but some parts of his education are somewhat deficient. So when he emerges into the modern world, the naive 35 year old is in for something of an adventure. As he-with the accompaniment of a girl he meets, ironically named Eve-learns and experiences all the world has to offer including love. Adam is the greenhorn to end all others and the comedy mostly rests on how he handles situations. The picture constantly seems to find new ways to keep the same joke fresh-which is no easy feat. Something else the film manages to do that most comedies fail too, is it doesn't purely rely on being gross for laughs and neither is it completely asinine. The latter is mainly because it doesn't want to simply portray Adam as a dimwit. Despite his unworldiness and simplicity, the film wishes to also accentuate his merits and value. This works in large part because of what a charming and likeable actor Brendan Fraser is. Amd despite being so callow, Adam isn't irritating and a character you can invest in.Blast From The Past takes an intresting premise and actually delivers on it. Supported by some amusing performances and sturdy writing, the picture stays funny for the majority of its 112 minutes.

reviews.review_title: It shouldn't work, but it's great
reviews.content: The name of this film is rubbish, the synopsis makes it sound like a really tired idea, and I'm not really a huge fan of Brendan Fraser.But, you know what, this was great fun in an eek, dare I say it, wholesome family sort of way, and the way films used to be made - something for everyone, lots of very original funny bits, some little digs at the American psyche.So, overall it's a happy, fun and thoughtful little film that deserves much better than the 6.5ish average it gets here. Fraser is superb, Spacek is hilarious, and Christopher Walken is, well, Christopher Walken, but I can't help but love his stuff...Put your cynicism to one side and just enjoy a sweet, very classy little movie that has great heart and doesn't over-Hollywood itself.

reviews.review_title: Most meaningful if you grew up in the 50s! But everyone will enjoy.
reviews.content: "Blast From The Past" plays on the cold war climate in the USA during the 1950s and 1960s. I clearly remember doing emergency drills at school. That is, what to do if we received word that Russia had bombed us. I also remember a few neighbors building their own 'bomb shelter' at home, stocked with food and water, in case there was an attack.This 1999 movie stars Brendan Fraser as Adam Webber, whose father Calvin (played with great comic timing by Christopher Walken) was a technical geek who built the bomb shelter of all bomb shelters. Knowing that radiation from a nuclear bomb attack would take years to decay, he built a shelter with systems to allow them to live in it for 35 years.Most of the SPOILERS follow. One day Calvin hears a loud bang and rushes his pregnant wife into the shelter, sure it was the beginning of a nuclear attack. So sure, he activated the locking device that would only open after 35 years. So Adam was born and raised in the shelter, his only contact with the outside world those things his dad and mom, Helen (Sissy Spacek, another of my favorites), taught him. And they did give him a very good education.Finally, all grown up, Adam is allowed to surface to get family supplies and assess the situation. Naturally everything is strange to him, and he finds out it was not a nuclear attack after all that had driven his family underground, but a military jet crashing onto their home. He meets Eve (Alicia Silverstone) who he convinces to help him. They have unique ways of raising cash with baseball cards. And eventually Adam and Eve become a couple. Who would have thought?

reviews.review_title: Pleasantville Knock-Off...And Not In A Good Way
reviews.content: Apparently, there was a time in film-making history (1999) where goofy Brendan Fraser antics and cutesy Alicia Silverstone smiles could be counted on to carry a film. Perhaps that "played" better in the late 90s than it does now, but for all the world this feels like a cheap, odd knock-off of 1998's "Pleasantville".For a basic plot summary, "Blast from the Past" is the story of Adam (Fraser), who is born and lives until age 35 in a fallout shelter when fanatical father (Christopher Walken) and mother (Sissy Spacek) believe the U.S. has been attacked by Russian nuclear capabilities (in reality, a plane accident on the front lawn). When "enough time has passed to eliminate the possibility of fallout", Adam ascends up into a world he is by no means ready for, where he meets Eve (Silverstone).There is one big problem with this movie and it is very easy to identify: They should have "played the material straight". "Pleasantville", released a year before this one, was able to take 50s nostalgia and make a poignant film out of it. "Blast" could have the very same type of setup, but instead chooses to go the "farcical comedy" route to great detriment. Every time you think the film might be on to something, it has to stoop to a cringe-worthy joke or do something ridiculous to try and justify the budding Adam/Eve relationship. Simply put, the film belongs squarely in the "rom/com" or even straight comedy genre, with barely a hint of serious drama or character- building present.I know that Silverstone had the "girl-next-door cute" thing going on for awhile and Fraser was the "dopey hunky guy", but (at least for me) that combination can't justify a movie like this. At times, it actually seems a bit embarrassing to see Walken & Spacek giving their all in such a sub- par effort.Thus, though potentially playing much better in the right climate (1990s), there is no getting around the fact that this isn't a quality film. It wastes a perfectly interesting setup by choosing not to pursue character development and going for the "caricature" approach instead.

This film reminds me of both Elf and Splash, where the character who has been somewhere for ages discovers the new world of present society. Basically inventor Calvin Webber (Christopher Walken) built a strong bomb shelter under his house, and he and wife Helen Thomas Webber (Carrie's Sissy Spacek) become convinced that a nuclear blast happened, but they can't get out for 35 years, they are currently in the 1960s. When this time has passed their son, Adam (Brendan Fraser) is grown up and goes up to try and fit in to the world of the 1990s. Along the way he meets new friends Eve Rustikoff (Alicia Silverstone) and Troy (A Bug's Life's Dave Foley). It is Adam's naive nature, politeness and lack of all intelligence that not only makes him weird, but wins Eve's heart. Also starring Joey Slotnick as Soda Jerk/ Archbishop Melker. The highlight of the film for me is when Adam dances with two blonde women when looking for a girlfriend or wife, he is really good. Good!

reviews.content: I saw Blast From The Past and it was wonderful,It is about a family consisting of a father and a pregnant mother is the early 60's. They thought there was going to be a nuclear war so they hid in a nuke proof bunker for decades ? Does anyone see a flaw in this ?
