reviews.review_title: Oh my lucky stars, this is a great movie!
reviews.content: This is one of the funniest movies I've seen in a while. I'm sitting here laughing just thinking about it. I love Christopher Walken's and Sissy Spacek' quirkiness in the movie. The whole cast is great! This is a great entertaining movie to watch if you want to get a good laugh.
I love this movie I think is so sweet and the story is different. Love all the actors too...

Boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl. It's an age-old story that's always satisfying. But this one gets a boost from an original plot that adds a new twist on the old yarn. The Webbers, thinking the Big One has exploded in 1962 lock themselves away in a fallout shelter for 35 years. Their son, born in the shelter, emerges from the bunker a 35 year-old boy looking to fall in love. He finds a hip 1990s girl who, like everyone else, finds him stiff and weird. But, with all the lessons and instructions from his parents, he surprises as a sort of renaissance Garp. With solid performances by Walken and Spacek, and credible contributions from Fraser and Silverstone, the whole film ends up as better than average entertainment.

I only watched this movie, because I have kids - and there isn't much else out there we can all enjoy.Boy, was I delightfully surprised! I laughed almost the entire movie through, well, except for most of the scenes with Alicia Silverstone in them.  The rest of the cast was a blast - particularly Brendan Fraser and Sissy Spacek.This movie had more than laughs. Blast from the Past was a heartfelt paean to the manners of the Kennedy years. It wasn't preachy, just a good yarn.If I could nit pick, though, I'd complain that gay men are now overused as the sympathetic understanding witty sidekicks. That's the new gay man stereotype. That's better than sissies or psychos, but can we move on now?

reviews.review_title: Worth seeing for Brendan Frashure alone
reviews.content: One could have fun chipping away at the goofy premise of "Blast From the Past" (*** out of ****).  Why is Brendan Frashure so cheerful after being cooped up in an underground bomb shelter with nobody but his parents for 35 years (even one as luxurious as this one)?  With all that time on their hands, why didn't his parents have another baby to keep him company?  Why didn't the father (supposedly a genius) have a radio underground so he could keep in touch with the world outside the bomb shelter?  Still I was willing to suspend my disbelief.  The film's makers maintain a fast pace and a light touch throughout (attributes the plodding and heavy-handed "Pleasantville" could have used in abundance) and the cast is wonderful.  Walken puts his usual persona of menacing eccentricity to refreshingly benign use, Spacek is always fun when she's being ditsy and Alicia Silverstone finds the right blend of hope and cynicism.  Dave Foley is good in the 90's equivalent of the Eve Arden role of the 40's.  The best friend and confidante of the leading lady is now an unthreatening gay man.  (The writers carefully avoid having him fall for Frashure himself.)  But it's buoyant Brendan who really keeps the whole movie afloat.  Just when you think you don't want to see him playing any more "child men" he finds wonderful new nuances in the role. All-in-all, good fun.  Loved the sequence in the 40's nightclub.

reviews.review_title: ridiculous premise and plot but comedy at least charming
reviews.content: Seeing some of these idiot reviews makes me understand how people voted for Trump and keep TV shows on the air and make Kardashians wealthy and believe Foxnews is close to being newsJust a few ridiculous premises... 1. no radio in the shelter? 2. no phone to contact relatives either during the stay or once they return to the surface?? 3. not one trip to a library or school to research the past 35 years?? 4. just a few hours of watching TV in his hotel would have wised him up to modern times ?? 5. stocks went up even in the 50's ...why not be aware they'd be worth much more now ??if you put logic aside...the movie becomes slightly believable...I emphasize slightlythere's been plenty of TV shows/movies made already that dealt with the "fish out of water" scenario when living in a different time period ..either past or future...ie. "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court" "Hot Tub Time Machine" "Back to the Future" 1,2,3 etc. watch one of those

This is probably one of those movies that gets made as part of a contract fulfillment . . . not because it is a story that _must be told._There is nothing really new nor groundbreaking here. Competent performances portraying only mildly "attractive" characters. Time- filler at best.

I had mixed emotions after seeing this movie. At times I really enjoyed it and at others, I thought it dragged on. This is not a bad movie to rent or see in the dollar theatre but definitely not worth full admission.The story basically revolves around the idea that a family believes that nuclear war is imminent and baracade themselves in a bomb shelter for 35 years. During this time, they have a son (Fraser) and raise him in this shelter into his 30s. What happens after the baracade's time lock releases them, is that the son ventures above ground into a different world and time (1990s) to gather supplies for the shelter. As you can guess, he suffers a bit of a culture shock. He encounters Silverstone's character (the first female he's ever seen besides his mother), and develops a crush on her. Through a series of events that the two characters go through, Silverstone's character realizes that she's fallen in love with Fraser, and vice versa.Keep in mind, I've simplied the main plot but the point is that it really isn't that strong a plot. You could miss pieces of the movie and not really miss anything at all. There are some nice moments but in the end I really didn't feel like I was into the movie. The humor was good in some parts but quite often it just wasn't that funny.Overall, this isn't a bad movie, but, it isn't a good movie either. There wasn't really anything memorable about the movie to make me think about it once I turned it off.....6/10.

Okay, maybe Brenden Frasier ISN'T as suave or as amazing as Carey Grant(who is?), but he is a close second.This movie is a "chick flick",  with lots of romantic cliches (Perry Como!), but oh wow, the two leads have great chemistry... not a complex movie, just awonderful, romantic comedy, with enough twists and turns to be fun. Yes, it's predictable (the boy HAS to get the girl, after all), but this is a sweet movie.Rent this film, sit down with your girlfriend (or boyfriend), and you'll have a fun evening together.

reviews.review_title: Detailed revelations regarding life in fallout shelter . .
reviews.content: This is a way cool movie, giving laughter and good aftertaste.  We went right out to buy yacht batteries, frozen chicken and pipe tobacco.  Sissy Spacek and Christopher Walken give finely tuned performances . . . Brendan Fraser works well.  And for Alicia Silverstone -- it's not easy being a modern woman.    This is a movie to lighten you up . . .  to delight us with sly jokes and fascinating details. We'll talk about the serious stuff tomorrow . . . .

reviews.review_title: Cute. Good message that could have been carried further.
reviews.content: A cute film that seems to be saying "People were nicer in the 1950's than they are today." Brendan Frasier plays a character that is a little bit George of the Jungle, a little bit Forrest Gump, and little bit Chance the Gardener.

reviews.review_title: like the fall out shelter this comedy love story takes time to build
reviews.content: Having read a review on the IMDb I did not expect to stay interested in this slow burning story line. It really only kicked off when Brendan Frsser reached 35yo and was sent out into down town Los Angeles to buy supplies for another 10 Years for him and his parent in their Bunker. How he came to be born in a Nuclear Fall Out Shelter as big as a warehouse stuffed full of every conceivable product including a trout farm and external heat detectors but not a Geiger Counter constitutes a largely irrelevant prologue but stick with it as the Love Story between Adam and Eve eventually leaves a very warm feeling and probably before Adam. Beautifully acted this totally implausible plot could equally have been staged in a theatre and might have been tried out there first by Bill Kelly who wrote the screenplay. And it was only as I came to write this review that I remembered that Brendan Fraser was the too good Canadian Mountie in "North and South" and just as good in this. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Light hearted funny and almost possible
reviews.content: I could almost imagine something like this happening, though not for 35 years.A good light hearted film, good performances all round. Loved the elevator references ;-)

reviews.review_title: Very good at what it is supposed to be!
reviews.content: Blast From the Past does well what it intends.  I don't want to overanalyze and just accept it for what is.  It is a well constructed film that puts a young man born in a bomb shelter during the Cuban missile crisis of the '60's and immerses him in the culture of the late '90's with all the changes in custom, languge, invention, and dress. The movie is develop ed well in that what is learned and the items brought from underground serve and fit well into the above ground story.  The soundtrack also matches the mood and reflects well the eras and passages of time.  Very good performances were made by Mr. Walken as the eccentric scientist father, Ms. Spacek as the mother, and espe cially fine performance for Mr. Fraser for whom this lead role could not have been better cast.  His innocence, intelligence, genteel charm, and strength both physical and emotional all show in his performance. I believe that those who see him as a one dimensional character are wrong and should see this as well as Gods And Monsters in which he also gave an excellent performance.  I'm not saying he'll develop to Tom Hanks or Robin Williams who had their starts in light comedy but I'm not saying he won't and very well might.  As you can no doubt tell I enjoyed the film.  Three stars!!!

I loved this movie!! Alicia Silverstone is fine and to me I think she did a better job than Brendon Fraser but he was also great in this movie too! The storyline to this is very different but it was very enjoyable. Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek were also good actors in this movie., but wouldn't they get bored down there. I know they didn't know much about what was on top of them. 5 ***** stars all the Way!!!!!

reviews.review_title: This is a great feel-good movie
reviews.content: Take this movie with a grain of salt.  Sure it's not a masterpiece of American cinema, but how many modern movies are?  This is a cute heart warming romantic comedy.  Although certain inconsistencies between our reality and the movie's are extremely evident, they needn't be dwelled upon. Brendan Fraser's performance in this movie is somewhat goofy but genuinely endearing, the parents (Walken and Spacek) are hilarious, and Alicia Silverstone also carries off her role serviceably, but not as well as the other actors in this film.  Still, it's a great movie to rent and I thoroughly recommend it to any romantic comedy fans out there, as well as to any Brendan Fraser fans.

reviews.review_title: Affectionate clever and knowing look at 90s life
reviews.content: This is a little belter of a film. Not an Oscar winner by a long way, but one of those films where you emerge from the cinema grinning from ear to ear and reckoning you have just had two hours of entertainment.Christopher Walken plays Calvin Weber, a Communist-paranoid egghead only just this side of sane. So worried is he about the Communist threat that he builds an underground shelter for when the balloon goes up. During the Cuban missile crisis, an air crash convinces him things are going to get very hot and noisy, so he heads for the shelter with his slightly dotty wife Helen (played with a great deal of glee by Sissy Spacek; where has she been for the last n years?), sealing the locks to prevent them going out for 35 years, by which time he calculates the radiation will have subsided.Helen is pregnant, and gives birth to Adam, who for the first 35 years of his life lives underground in the shelter, which is eerily designed to look like the neighbourhood the Webers are sure has been destroyed. Helen even goes shopping' for food in a reproduction of the local grocery store. As time goes on both Calvin and Helen go slightly (more) mental, while doing their level best to bring up Adam to uphold the early 60s values they espouse - politeness, the importance of education, all nuclear family stuff (and I am sure that gag occurred to director Hugh Wilson and writer Bill Kelly).35 years having elapsed, Adam is sent out to get new supplies, and there is a shift to the more familiar territory of a tale of an innocent abroad. However, it is all played with a great deal of charm and sense of fun, and the underlying joke never goes stale. Brendan Fraser as Adam is convincing as the intelligent but dumb, unworldly young man anxious to find a girl (One that doesn't glow in the dark' quips Calvin), getting lost in the big wide world, and encountering the hard bitten, streetwise Eve. Alicia Silverstone carries this role beautifully, and also gets some of the best lines. During one conversation with Adam, she wails It never works out with me and men!' When asked by Adam exactly why not, she says Because men always seem to go for my legs, or my butt, or my hair, or any combination of the three.' So what's the problem? I think you are very attractive.' The problem is that I go for legs, butts, and hair too. So I end up with guys who are even more shallow than I am. (Pause) If you can imagine that.'Adam recruits Eve to help him stock up on supplies for the shelter, and also to try to find him a wife, and she reluctantly agrees (What sort of girl do you want?' One who isn't a mutant.' Oh right, no dogs huh?'). She is aided and abetted by her gay flatmate Troy, played with just the right degree of campness by David Foley (who he? IMDB here I come.). And guess what? She falls for Adam, but she really, really falls for him. This dawns on her during an excruciatingly funny sequence in a retro dancehall, where Adam clears the floor by jiving with two beautiful strangers (he has been taught to dance by his mother), and then falls into the clutches of femme fatale Sophie, whom Eve cannot abide.It all looks as if it will work out when Adam later returns to Eve's apartment, but foolishly she asks him where he is from. His honest reply leads her to suspect he is completely barking, and she sends for the authorities to pick him up. Adam escapes, but as he goes tells Eve and Troy go to his hotel room to tidy up his possessions. Troy finds some stock certificates that Calvin bought for Adam in the early 60s, and it dawns on Eve that Adam was telling the truth. Eve then gets another great line as she admits to Troy she was wrong. Troy:Eve, you met the nicest, gentlest, politest, kindest' Eve:Richest.' Troy:richest young man you have ever met.' Eve:And I tried to have him committed.'I will not say how it resolves itself, but it involves a long running subplot about a religious cult, and a riotously funny scene in an adult video store.This is a terrific feelgood film, but the way in which Calvin and Helen fall apart over time lends it a more serious, darker edge. Great performances, cracking script, neat direction, clever camerawork, and costume design that strays into the inspired (in the scenes just before Adam leaves the bunker, see if you can spot where his jacket came from).Magic, and good value for money. See it. I am not exaggerating how good this is.

A warm, touching and hilarious! film. Brendan Fraser is incredible in his role as an extremely out-of-touch 35 year old thrust into the 1990s. His character comes across as so earnest and lovable--we know we really shouldn't laugh at him, but the end result is just so comical! In the role of Fraser's girlfriend, Alicia Silverstone is her usual self--believable and incredibly sweet. (But seriously, how many 35 year olds can get a 22 year old steady girlfriend?) It's fun to watch as Alicia's character swings from mistrust of Fraser's (is he a stalker?) to insane jealousy (lady, get your hands off my man!) Joey Slotnick steals the show as a drunk turned cult leader--it's worth the $8.50 just to see him.

reviews.review_title: Interesting performances hidden in lightweight movie
reviews.content: Blast From the Past, it's a rather harmless but cute, slightly silly movie. What makes it really worth watching are two great performances by Sissy Spacek and Christopher Walken as the parents. They are truly wonderful. The most annoying thing in the movie was the almost obligatory insertion of a gay character. I liked the sweet, truly nice character played by Brendan Frasier. The science in the movie has some problems but it's possible to suspend belief and just enjoy it.

Brandon Fraser is enjoyable in this anti-Austin Powers pic, although his character is very similar to that in George of the Jungle, Dudley Do Right, Airheads, and so on. Alicia Silverstone doesn't really work in this picture though, I can never really buy how they meet and the reason she sticks to him. David Foley, playing his character as he did with so many other gay characters from Kids in the Hall, is extremely enjoyable as Alicia's conscience and roommate.

reviews.review_title: Funny, romantic, extraordinary movie that makes you happy
reviews.content: I think this is an excellent movie. Nice romantic story but still weird enough to be funny. Idea of people coming from past to present isn't new but I think this movie is a fine example of that genre. This movie made me happy.

reviews.review_title: Quirky, cute and funny, what's not to like?!
reviews.content: First let me say that I have been a Brendan Frasier fan since I saw him in his first(?) film where he played a revived caveman attending modern-day high school.  His character was naive, clueless, charismatic and hunky, just about the same role that he plays in "Blast from the Past", but that's OK, because it works! In this film he and his family have been in a funky fallout shelter for 35 years, thinking that there has been an atomic blast in 1962.  The set for the fallout shelter is very imaginative and true to the style of the '60's. The family's life below ground is portrayed in a funny and clever manner, as they take you through 35 years of coping with a limited environment and human contact of the closest kind.  But finally the day comes when the doors unlock and up comes the family.  The first meetings that they have with the "mutants" are hilarious.  Once Brendan is wandering around on the surface, the film gets a little more predictable, but it is always fun.Sissy Spacek and Christopher Walken are excellent as Mom and Pop, funny, eccentric and endearing. All in all, this is a very enjoyable film and well worthing renting.

reviews.review_title: Contrived story to get to a particular idea
reviews.content: An example of bad writing is when you want to get to an idea: Guy appears 35 years in the future and is a fish out of water - a single joke movie. So, how do you get to this idea?--by bad writing: having a family live in a bomb shelter for 35 years. The movie doesn't deal with the psychological depression, rotting food, removal of waste, things aging, breaking down...etc. The 35 years pass as though this was a shelter funded by NASA. In short, suspend your disbelief so we can get to the funny situation of a guy showing up in a future far from the supposedly 1950s bland homogeneous lifestyle that appeared on some TV shows at the time. This has been done in other movies and done much better. So, their house is not just turned into a mall...but the lily white middle class neighborhood becomes a porn infested ghetto in 35 years....it's OK...suspending your disbelief is what you are supposed to do for the entire film. It just can't get any dumber.

reviews.review_title: If only every family was this innocent...
reviews.content: Cute, funny, and definitely original, Blast From the Past was a terrific film.  This is Alicia Silverstone's best performance since Clueless in 1995. I also really enjoyed the characters of Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek.  Mostly, however, Brendan Fraser steals the show.  His innocent and mannerly character still prevailed over every encounter in the "New World" of 1999. This movie had a carried a real message of value and most of all, love.I hope to see more movies like this soon...

reviews.review_title: So stupid, but it got some good laughs out of me...
reviews.content: I don't know how I missed this movie when it came out in the 90s. It was in my suggested movies on my Google TV. Probably bc I watch Clueless way to much also staring Silverstone. The movie reminded me of the corny movies my family rented from Blockbuster on the weekends. Over the top, unbelievable, and a predictible rom com ending. You know what you're getting into, and it's ok. Relax and enjoy.

Brendan Fraser (GODS AND MONSTERS) is a congregation of grimy transients' mistaken messiah and time-capsuled love interest for unemployed Alicia Silverstone, who is wooed by the simplicity of his Cuban missile crisis-era gallantry and knows the value of old baseball cards.  Turns out his alcoholic mom and paranoid scientist dad (Sissy Spacechick and Christopher Walken) had invested in Polaroid and IBM shares in 1962--before they sealed themselves in a bomb shelter for 35 years, thinking the commies had invaded--making their clueless son a billionaire.  After some zaniness they all live happily ever after, learning to accentuate the positive. Co-starring Dave Foley (A BUG'S LIFE, NEWSRADIO, KIDS IN THE HALL), who tries his hand at a Valley gay roommate.  Songs by Dean Martin, Barry White, Village People, familiar Dishwalla and Everclear; swing numbers by Squirrel Nut Zippers and Cherry Poppin' Daddies; and lots of so-smooth Perry Como, the perfectly warmed-over, bottled Pepsi accompaniment for child-rearing in a vacuum whilst fashions, sights and sounds of three decades in L.A. change above ground.  Randy Newman contributes yet another incarnation of the same dippy Louisiana clarinet-n-piano molasses he's been serving up for the past 30 years.

Hugh Wilson's "Blast From the Past" is going to get a lot of points from me because the premise is so original, excellent, and genuinely outstanding. But that's about it, except, Christopher Walken is pretty amusing as a paranoid inventor.OK, Mom (Sissy Spacek), Dad (Christopher Walken), and Son (Brendan Fraser) lock themselves underground for thirty-five years. Thirty-five years later... Dad is sick and Mom sends Son out with an absurd list of items to bring back to their underground lair. While doing his EXTREMELY ELABORATE grocery shopping, Son falls in love with a pretty young girl (played by Alicia Silverstone). My question is: Where is the chemistry between Fraser and Silverstone? Where is more of Christopher Walken when you need him? Besides the premise and Walken, what is there to like about this movie?"Blast From the Past" represents a neat, little idea that, quite unfortunately, got caught up in the Hollywood press and the typical hype. It doesn't live up to its hype. This is a movie that should have had a lower budget, actors instead of movie stars (Christopher Walken not withstanding), and should've been directed by a talented indie who knows this type of bizarro material.My dream "Blast From the Past": A satiric, laugh-out-loud comedy, rewritten and directed by John Waters. Yes, J.W. would be the perfect choice for this flick.The real "Blast From the Past": An odd Hollywood movie with a premise and supporting actor that upstage EVERYTHING else. Rated PG-13. 111 minutes. 5 out of 10.

the idea for this movie was the best ive heard of in a long time.  its original and captivating.  but it did lack a little in the execution and realism.  still though i give it a sound 9. because yes, it was that good. i dare say as well that this is probably brendan fraser's finest movie. most people dont like his others such as george of the jungle and monkeybone but i judge them by how well he acts in the role that he is playing, NOT in the role that he is cast.  if you judge by his roles then brendan is a nitwit, but by how he acts he's brilliant.  i mean think about it, if you think he's a nitwit thats great cuz in dudley do-right and bedazzled... thats what he is!

99 just started and I think this is a candidate for the worst movie of the year. This movie is very dumb, very pointless, and INCREDIBLY BORING. I walked out because it just was not funny AT ALL. It was just brainless and dumb.

reviews.review_title: Blast from the Past is a surprisingly, enjoyable, romantic comedy.
reviews.content:
Blast from the Past is a pleasant surprise.  The plot is a lot more interesting than I expected, and the acting was rather good. Not even Alicia Silverstone (Batman: Forever) could ruin this movie for me (and that is saying a lot). Christopher Walken's performance (as always) is a must see. Mr. Walken plays a quirky character named Calvin Webbers. Calvin is a "mad genius" who gets ready for the end of the world by building an elaborate bomb shelter that would care for his family for 35 years.  The 35 years in the shelter make for some entertaining moments, but the real fun starts when Brendan Fraser's character (Adam Webbers) makes his way to the surface.
Adam encounters a world that is not only strange, but also terrifying to him. Brendan does a great job playing the naive wanderer trying to find supplies for his family and love for himself.  I don't want to give too much of the movie away, so I will wrap this review up. Blast from the Past has its share of laughs, and a few touching moments. This is the epitome of a "great" date movie.  I gave this movie eight out of ten stars (mostly because Walken's performance).P.S. Keep your eyes open for Dave Foley (from News Radio, and the Kids in the Hall).  You'll be happy you did.

Often simple story lines work best, and Blast from the Past fits that rule. It's a delicate little gem. Silverstone in one of her better roles, and Brendan Fraser really becomes the 35 year old goody two shoes meeting today's world for the first time in his life. Basically everything works in this sympathetic little film, from Silverstone's gay friend ***** minor spoilers (Not surprisingly Fraser never gets the message when Silverstone describes her friend as such) to the Archbishop and his weird collection of devoted followers who think they have seen Jesus, his father and mother Mary pop out of their underground dwelling. ***** I think the script writer and director managed to squeeze about every conceivable time lapse misconception in the scenario in a way that works and skipped the overly obvious ones that would have made this film a corny event. Nowhere the film lapses into a cheap series of "Seve Martin/Leslie Nielsen" type jokes just for the sake of inducing a laugh. Focus remains with the inevitable storyline, which is rather predictable, something that can ruin a film, but sometimes work in its favour, as it does here. A heart warming pastime, well worth taking up space in your DVD collection. Watching such a film one could easily be tempted to think making it was a breeze. Having seen tons of other movies in the same genre certainly proves making a good film, even a light comedy, is nothing but. Glad I watched it, watched it again, and I will certainly give it another go in the near future.

reviews.review_title: This movie really is a blast
reviews.content: I had so much fun watching this film. Brendan Fraser seems to have a knack for playing cluelessly cool characters. The nostalgic 60's vibe in the beginning that was carried out all the way to the end of the movie was so satisfactory as well. The concept of Alicia Silverstone accidentally falling in love with Fraser through jealousy was more realistic than your average rom com and couldn't honestly find anything I didn't enjoy about this film. Tons of one liner gems in this one as well.

Working in a video store, I see tons of movies -- most of which are pretty awful. My tolerance level for bad films is at rock bottom, so only the most creative and witty ones can hold my attention. Blast From the Past, however, is a refreshing and exciting throwback to the days when a good script really mattered. I really didn't expect it to be so offbeat and intelligent yet so natural and down to earth, so it was a truly pleasant surprise. But I think it's time we take care of a few matters:1. No two characters in any movie, for any reason, should ever again be named Adam and Eve.2. Having gay people in a movie is not - repeat - NOT enough of a reason to play YMCA or any other Village People song.3. Randy Newman must be shot. Let's just get it over with.Despite these minor flaws, the strong performances  and intelligent scripting throughout made it fun. Dave Foley does an excellent job, as do all the everyday people confronted with Brendan Frasier's character. I give it 9 of 10.

reviews.review_title: Should not have come to the present...
reviews.content: I wanted to enjoy this movie, largely because I have always felt that Alicia Silverstone has received a bad wrap from the press.  While I don't agree with them calling her "Fatgirl," I can say that the press won't be any friendlier with her new role in "Blast from the Past," due to the fact that this movie is almost unwatchable.  Take a cast, two of which are synonymous with bad movies (Walken, Spacek), and one who has not appeared in any recent pictures (Silverstone), and watch them struggle through this movie.  At times, I couldn't tell if Silverstone was playing Cher from "Clueless," Emily from "Excess Baggage," or her "too cool" 90's character Eve.  Walken, who has gone downhill since "A View to a Kill," continues to gain my sympathy for staying in the business.  As far as plot goes, even far-fetched movies need certain elements of reality, and those elements are clearly lacking from the film.  Adam, for instance, speaks French fluently, yet he has no concept of homosexuality?  As far as characters go, Spacek plays an annoying mother to Adam who practically begs the audience to laugh at her. And Eve's overly-stereotypical-homosexual friend just makes you want to beat him senselessly.  Somewhere between all these inane characters and bad acting lies a plot, which is sometimes forsaken for the "character development" that just doesn't happen.  I won't even recommend waiting for this one to come to video.  Be it in the near present or far future, avoid this one.

reviews.review_title: Decent film which lacks a punch
reviews.content: This is a cute, albeit forgettable comedy romance about a man who comes out in the real world after living in a nuclear fallout shelter all his life. Strange to see both Alicia Silverstone and Brendon Fraser completely fall off the face of this Earth now but back in 1999 they were as big a stars as one could be. The chemistry is lacking to be honest and the film sort of just plods through though there are some cute moments scattered about. Blast from the Past is a decent watch if there is nothing else to see. Otherwise you're better off renting Clueless or The Mummy.

'Blast from the Past' is a pleasant romantic comedy. Fraser is always effective playing naive. And it's hard not to enjoy everything Walken does: he's always great. Spacek is very funny as a women bored by her constant surroundings and Silverstone plays a modern woman with zest. Foley is as funny as ever. All and all a satisfying romantic comedy.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant variation on "fish out of water" theme with Fraser doing usual idiot-hunk schtick.
reviews.content: Brendan Fraser stars along with Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek in this "what-if" high concept comedy about an innocent coming out of a bomb shelter after thirty five years of life with only his parents and "Honeymooners" and "I Love Lucy" reruns. One can almost hear the pitch to the studio in this one, but director Hugh Wilson delivers the satire and commentary on both the early sixties commie paranoia and degenerative fin de seicle society.  The subtext of the comedy, i.e. that if you were raised with only decent parents and no outside influences (and your dad happens to be a slightly wacky genius) you might actually be a great person lends weight to what might otherwise be a bit of fluff.  Walken and Spacek are brilliant as usual, Dave Foley, formerly of Kids in the Hall fame, is hilarious as the wise roomie of Alicia Silverstone. The side stories especially of the gradually rundown soda jerk, are wonderful.  Worth the rental and then some. Even if you watch it only for the sherbet-colored world of 1962.

A fairly entertaining film with Fraser playing a Tom-Hanks-in-"Big" character and Silverstone proving once again that yes, she's a young 20-something from California.Walken and Spacek are thrown into the mix in a bit of odd casting but they end up proving themselves as the perfect "out of this time" couple. Walken is the Commie-crazed father who buries his family in a fall-out shelter. Spacek is the 50s- or 60s-era housewife who goes bonkers from the isolation and enjoys her Champagne cocktails a little too much.The script, despite a truly contrived plot, does show some moments of good writing. One in particular has Silverstone and Foley playing off one another as she tries to discover Fraser's whereabouts. Plenty of goofy and smile-inducing "out of his element" humor, too.Fraser does a great job playing his all-too usual comedic role -- the lunk-headed hero. Silversone also dips into her past performances but manages to be undeniably cute as the pouty Eve.The verdict? Good date-and-popcorn movie, but other than that, just a so-so film with a better than average cast.

I felt asleep watching this movie, right when Walken and Spacek finished their turn, the shelter was opened and their son (Brendan Fraser) came out.I must admit, I don't like Brendan Fraser's acting style. Every time he's just... "Brendan Fraser"... Silverstone was no help here, okay, she's "nice", but then? It seems to me that some ideas used in this movie come from "Back to the future" and it sequels... I do not see the necessity to say "if there was an oscar for such movies"... but then I see the av. vote to be almost 7 and wonder...This one is awful. 1 of 10

reviews.review_title: A fair film that is boring at the beginning but the second half of it is interesting
reviews.content: This film has original plot. It starts with the party in 1962 as the father of the main character (Christopher Walken) telling a joke. He is a genius but strange at the same time and when all the people there watch TV news and Pr. Kennedy tells about missile lunch Walken asks everyone to leave and after that He and his wife (Sissy Spacek) stay at the underground bunker. The main character Adam (Brendan Fraser) lives for 35 years of his life there and this part of the film is quite boring but then when he gets on to the streets of modern Los Angeles it gets much more interesting especially when Eva (Alicia Silverstone) enters the film. She is a real pleasure for the eyes. Summarizing it's an interesting family comedy with elements of fantastic and it's an average one: not great but not poor either. It has many fun moments so if you can skip the first 20 or so minutes of slow start then it'll make you smile and even laugh.

reviews.review_title: I'd like to be more positive, but it was disappointing
reviews.content: (Hints at ending but no real spoiler.) Believe me, I don't like writing negative reviews about something a lot of people have worked hard on - but it's difficult to be positive about Blast From The Past. It had an interesting plot and could perhaps have worked, if approached differently. Billed as a romantic comedy, this movie wasn't funny enough to be comic, and lacked the plausibility and emotional realism to be romantic. I admit, it had humorous moments, but mostly from minor characters. Brendan Fraser played the well meaning but basically weird guy stuck in a 1960s time warp. I really wanted to like his character, who could have been charming and sympathetic, and still had amusing quirks. As it was, Adam was completely over-acted and sent up for laughs, making him way too wacko to be in the least bit believable as a human being. The character had so much scope but ended up a joke. Forrest Gump proves that a lead role can be laughable and still make the audience care - so BFTP has no excuse. A disappointment from a talented actor. Best stick to fighting mummies, Brendan. Alicia Silverstone was the tart without a heart who was supposed to fall in love with Adam, but this stretched the `willing suspension of disbelief' way too far. After half an hour of watching her totally annoying, shallow and sour character, Eve, I was ready to reach for the stop button. I haven't seen her in many films but this one did nothing to endear me to Ms. Silverstone. The supporting cast were more impressive but sadly not enough to redeem BFTP. Maybe I missed the point with this film, but after watching Blast From the Past I felt cheated of my evening and my money. Watch it if you like.. but don't say I didn't warn you!

This film had everything going for it except one – the decadent attitude of the makers. The characteristic of decadence is that it believes in nothing, yet it feeds off anyone who believes in something. The film is obviously an expansion on the joke "Have you been living in a bomb shelter all these years!", but the slant on it is, "let's make fun on fifties morality". That's cheap. Good for a joke, but not for a full length film. If it needs to be stretched out into a film then fifties morality has to be built up before shooting it down. Therefore a good chunk of the film is taken up building fifties morality in the nuclear shelter of Calvin and his family. Since the makers have no respect for this kind of life, it comes across as unintended satire. We are supposed to laugh at crazy people minding morals and manners in a dugout, and at the same time we are not supposed to laugh, because morals and manners will become heroic qualities for the protagonist later on in the film. So it's, whatever suits the plot at any particular time. In other words, decadence! If they believed that fifties morality is bad, then we would have satire. If they believed it was good then we would have a sweet romantic comedy. But the people involved don't believe in anything really, and they are happy to maintain a snickering, subversive attitude throughout. Using all their skills in exploitation and manipulation, their purpose is no get a passable film together, meant for the shallow masses, who like them also believe in nothing. Except, of course, the quick buck.Taking all this into account, it's a good effort. Entertaining, and some good performances. Christopher Walken is particularly good. The premise is extremely far-fetched, and a lot of effort is gone into making it believable. Despite the efforts, it's barely believable to begin with, it stops being believable at all after Adam grows up and walks into the real world. This is where comedy is meant to tide things over, and it required a deft and conscientious touch to work. But it all goes wrong. It's heavy handed and insensitive most of the way. The heart of the film is not in the right place. We don't appreciate all the fun made of morality and manners. Not when the film itself is about the preciousness of morality and manners in the nihilistic nineties.

This movie is a waste of the acting talents of Sissy Spacek and Christopher Walken. It may be a waste of the acting talents of Brendan Fraser and Alicia Silverstone too, but since I don't think they've proven themselves to be as talented as Spacek and Walker (yet) that really isn't a major consideration.  If you want to see a recent movie that is funny, check out "Waking Ned Devine," "Office Space" or "Shakespeare in Love."

reviews.review_title: More funny than I imagined and an enjoyable film for the family.
reviews.content: Brendan Fraser is an overlooked talent and he does a superb job in this movie.  Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek had everyone in my family laughing simply with their mannerisms in character.  My daughter is 13 and I had no problems with her seeing this very humorous movie.  I was expecting a movie that was moderately funny, but I was laughing a lot more than I expected. Well worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: Adorable, I want to see it again
reviews.content: This was just adorable, funny, and romantic. This is one of Brendan Fraser's better performances. He does innocent, unspoiled and "just a little clueless" so well. Alicia Silverstone does a great job as well as a worldly, street smart girl of the "90's". Christpher Walken and Sissy Spacek are terrific as well, believable parents from that generation and that profession. The small details, the plot elements, the characterizations were all well-thought out.The movie makes a vivid contrast between the values and morals of the past and the present... right down to "manners"... as Troy so eloquently observes that he never realized they were "to show our respect" to other people... he always thought they were just to "act superior". At times, you can sense the modern girl, although taken unaware with this gentleman from the past, really seeing things she has never really seen in a man before.It was charming, funny and adorable. I'd like to see this one again.

reviews.review_title: A movie to watch if you need your spirits lifted.
reviews.content: Every now and then a movie comes along that simply is a joy to watch. Blast From The Past is one such movie.From the start the quick paced humour and ever-loving characters made this a joy to be carried along. I've got to admit, it's the most enjoyable 35 years I have ever spent!The plot would always bring laughs with the innocence of the 60's meeting the brassiness of the 90's. Strong performances by all characters made this movie a gem. One that not only provides a good belly laugh, but makes you feel good about some of those old fashioned things in life that still stick. It's not often that values are highlighted in movies as something that are fresh and missed.The good ol' days, well perhaps there was some good in them after-all!

If you want to see a good original movie you must see Blast from the past. Alicia Silverstone and Brendan Fraser playing nice, no very very very very good. And I musn't forget Cristopher Walken one of the best in Hollywood. Go see the movie today you won't be disappointed. Have Fun!

This movie lives up to its' potential well.Is very endearing and not laugh out loud funny, but funny enough.Wonderfully, classic 90's cast.A multi-era trip through nostalgia as I remember seeing it when I was very young.Truly a blast from the past itself now!

WARNING!! Plot Summary ahead! Don't be mislead by the hype! This is truly a horror picture! Mad scientist inters his wife & himself in an underground refuge. A son is born & the wife slowly becomes a shrieking alcoholic. 35 years pass & the son, a sort of idiot/savant, learns to speak in many languages. That's why he's a savant. He's also an idiot because he doesn't understand (I guess) what he's saying in any of them. The time comes for the family provisions to be replenished. Also, slurs Mom, for the son to get a nice, healthy wife! The son emerges to the surface and is greeted by a nightmarish vision of an apocalyptic Sodom & Gomorrah. His first verbal contact with a female is with a demeaning, scatterbrained floozy who puts him down at every turn. Naturally, he falls madly in love with her. Finally she accepts to go out with him, but dumps him as soon as she sees an ex boyfriend. (She is only attracted, she says, by guys with great butts!) The only possessions our "hero" took upon leaving his vault, were a cigar box full of old baseball cards (the value of which he knows nothing), and some bonds. Together, these make him a billionaire and the promiscuous shrew he's enamored of realizes she loves him too. Next step is to demolish for miles around all the area surrounding his underground retreat, landscape the grounds, and build a pretty house. Mom & Pop come up, meet the blushing bride, and Pop proceeds to go off, taking giant strides across the garden.
Very well done.  My son dragged me there and I can't thank him enough.  What a movie.  If you want a movie that entertains you and you feel good walking out the door, then this is it.

I caught this film on BBC2 in the UK back in 2002 I think and I thought it was a charming little film watched it again 18 years later and despite a long running time is still a charming little film better than the other Hugh Wilson/Brendan Fraser team up the awful Dudley do right.

It amazes me that someone expecting a deep script with an ingenious plotline would go see this movie. From the trailer one should be able to judge what kind of movie it is. It's silly and funny, with a little romance thrown in.Silverstone and Fraser shine, both are very funny, and NewsRadio's Dave Foley added a nice touch. Good direction, good acting, near hilarious script... I give it 8 stars out of 10.Check it out if ya need a laugh.

I agree with so many--this movie is wonderful.  I tuned in as Brendan was leaving the shelter.  From that strange beginning, I became enthralled with the story.  Brendan is fantastic.  Now I know who my favorite, sexiest male star is.  I agree with someone else who wrote that Alicia Silverstone's character is rather hard to understand.  The movie doesn't quite give us much about why she seems so hostile about men interested in her, and why she treats Brendan the way she does.  I laughed out loud when he said "I was going to ask you why he wears other men's underwear".  (re:  Ralph Lauren) Again, when his mom (Sissy Spacek) senses there's trouble by Adam's frantic entrance and asks what's wrong.  "I'm being followed by psychiatrists!" (his parents gasp--hilarious!)This movie is sweet and tender.  I wish more movies were like this one.

Strange to see both Alicia Silverstone and Brendon Fraser completely fall off the face of this Earth now but back in 1999 they were as big a stars as one could be. The chemistry is lacking to be honest and the film sort of just plods through though there are some cute moments scattered about. Blast from the Past is a decent watch if there is nothing else to see. Otherwise you're better off renting Clueless or The Mummy.

Fantastic - excellent cast, plot a little bit slow at first but the rest more than makes up for it. I could hardly believe that Eve was played by the same Alicia Silverstone who was in Clueless! She stole my heart as well as Adam's. I thought Adam's parents were hilarious at times, but poignant at others. Brilliant combination. I'd never seen Brendan Fraser before, and I was most impressed by how believable he was as the ultra-innocent Adam. Both lead players had that chemistry thing going on, but I really think Eve was the star.The ending left me feeling just a little flat, but I walked out of the theatre on Cloud 9 anyway.

reviews.review_title: This movie asks too much of you and simply doesn't deliver enough for your effort.
reviews.content: The main problem with this movie is that there isn't a single element in it that doesn't demand you to suspend your disbelief to a level you just can't and don't want to maintain.  If it were a wackier comedy, you could, but it's not.  It tried to be a nice, sweet film with a gentle theme, but it came off as awkward, inconsistent, and hackneyed.  It took an interesting premise (taking the phrase, "What, have you been living in a bomb shelter your whole life?" literally), and abused it silly until you just couldn't believe any part of it.

It is a cute little story of romance between two young people brought up in different times. Adam, a handsome young man brought up in 60s meets Eve, beautiful yet cynical young woman (of present day) who believes he is too good to be true.Adam's parents go into fallout shelter and lock themselves up for 35 years. He was lovingly nurtured by his parents' and grows up into a smart, intelligent and suave young man. But when he comes out of the shelter, the times are too changed. He meets Eve who thinks he is unreal. The ensuing story is funny and at times hilarious. Troy (David Foley) eventually helps Eve realize that nothing is wrong with honesty, politeness and substance in one's character.Chris Walken and Sissy Spacek are wonderful as Adam's parents. Brendan Fraser is excellent as Adam. David Foley is just right as Troy. Alicia is not bad as Eve - she could have done better.Soundtrack numbers like Mr Zoot Suit (Flying Neutrinos) and 'I See the Sun in Your Eyes' (Peter Henriksen) are apt and very good.

I like it i thought the story was not bad 
him staying in the shelter and then exploring the world and falling in love .. i thought it was good

Good idea, well acted, worth seeing.  Alicia plays her character well - not cutesy like "Clueless".  Probably only Kids in the Hall fans will really appreciate Dave Foley's acting - it's basically his female character minus the wig.  He made me laugh.  Brendan made me laugh a few times, too.  Walken and Spacek are great.

reviews.review_title: Fun, adorable, Brendan's sweet, cute & such a gentleman
reviews.content: This is a wonderful movie. I laughed out loud (embarrassing my daughter)!! If you've had a rough day, go see this movie, sit back and enjoy. And to top it all...Brendan's a real cutey!!!

reviews.review_title: Amazing caste EXCEPT for "Eve" or Alicia Silverstone
reviews.content: Great comedy, Brendan Fraser and Christopher walken at their best but it was a pain to watch that main actress "Eve" to try to act. I literally fast-forwarded every single scene that had her in it. Performances from almost all other caste members and the comedy were worth the watch

One of the most formulaic plots in Hollywood deals with that of the "fish out of water."  Namely, a character being stuck in a world in which he or she does not belong, and acting accordingly, to comic results.  One would think that after seeing the same setup time and time again, it would start to grow stale.  Yet, Hollywood keeps making these type of movies, and they, for the most part, are almost always entertaining (George of the Jungle, anything by Tim Burton, etc.).  I don't know how they do it, time and time again, but Hollywood has done it again with Blast From the Past.I loved this movie from the very beginning.  It opens with the two adult leads, played by Christopher Walken (in a terrific role, playing against his stereotype), and Sissy Spacek (also terrific) throwing a party.Sure, the movie is predictable.  But it's a lot of fun.  Fraser is terrific in the role of someone who hasn't left his parents side for 35 years.  The writing is lighthearted and fun, and everyone involved seems to be having a good time.The only real problem I had with the film involve a running gag about the resident of the building directly above the fallout shelter.  This was funny for a while, but they took the joke too far, and by the end, the joke got old.  The film was also a tad overlong, and the score was kind of lame at times.But these are very minor complaints, when you take into account how good the movie is as a whole.  I highly recommend this film. It is lighthearted, and very, very funny. It's a movie you can go to, and just have fun with.  I, for one, had a really good time.

reviews.review_title: This was the best movie I have seen in a long time
reviews.content: Brendan Fraser plays such a warm, loving character that one could not resist loving him. The movie has a great plot and a great cast. (I especially like Troy) I give this movie two thumbs way up, and think that everyone should go see it.

reviews.review_title: A little bit amusing and a big bit time killer.
reviews.content: This is a childish movie. Nevertheless it is very amusing at some points. If I compare it with American Pie I must say that the humor in Blast from the past is more friendly. More as if you laugh with the people instead of at them. The movie has no deeper meaning as so many other movies in this genre. If you want to lay back in the chair and just get amused for one and a half hour rent this movie. It is okidoki but not fantastic.

Rating:   2 1/2 starsThe Cuban missile crisis is looming. Prepared for such a potential catastrophe, Calvin (Christopher Walken) and Amanda (Sissy Spacek) Webber are waiting for the right moment to enter their state of the art bomb shelter which was secretly built below there home. Of course that moment arrives.Calvin is a scientific genius, a self-made millionaire (From patented inventions), and incredibly paranoid as he is sure the Cuban missile crisis is the inevitable catalyst to the end of the world, as we know it. His wife, Amanda (Sissy Spacek) is a stereotypical 1950's-type housewife.Calvin, in the middle of his house party, interprets a radio broadcast as his cue to enter the bomb shelter. He abruptly asks his guests to leave, his pregnant wife and himself enter the shelter just as an explosion occurs above. He thinks it's the end. It was only a disabled military jet that crashes into his home. He sets the time lock to exit at 35 years in the future when it will be safe to re-enter the atmosphere. His son, Adam (Brendon Fraiser) is born and raised for 35 years in the bomb shelter with all of the knowledge and morals of the late 1950's.The best moments of this movie were during the 35-year span in the shelter as Adam was being raised. Simultaneously, above the shelter, we see the construction of a soda shop that's operated by a mother and son (Joey Slotnick). We see them, along with their business, drastically change with the times. The writers during this part of the movie were creative, original, and funny.Question: As Adam walked out of the bomb shelter and into the light, did the writers feel this was a good time to walk out on the movie? The movie became the typical (Actually written better than typical) Hollywood formula of:1) Boy meets the beautiful girl, (Eve played by Alicia Silverstone) in which the writers assumed we were stupid enough to think that they could force such a quick and unlikely relationship with.2) Boy wants girl but must overcome the usual obstacles.3) Boy gets girl.4) And finally, let's have the, which is painfully obvious, happy ending.Performances were quite good. The real standout character was the soda jerk (Joey Slotnick). His character made several changes along the movie. He went from a 1950's style soda jerk to a burned out drugged induced and lost in the past hippie style figure. Watching these changes along with Joey's performance was a lot of fun.Generally speaking, the movie in itself was a lot of fun but its potential was never fulfilled. I don't understand how a script can be so strong in the first third and then neglected for the remainder. The writer's were good enough to have funny moments even in the formulated areas.I do recommend this movie. Most of this review was spent describing the 35-year span because this was the area that the writer's placed most of their efforts. Overall, this is a pretty funny and fun movie but it could have been so much more.

reviews.review_title: From Deer Hunter to this stinker? C'mon Chris!
reviews.content: After seeing the Deer Hunter, one of cinemas most prolific masterpieces, I was convinced that Christopher Walken may just be one of the most talented actors in my lifetime. Unfortunately all of the goodwill that he built up in Deer Hunter, and to a lesser extent Pulp Fiction, was spoiled by this stinker. This movie is absolutely dreadful. I expect Brendan Fraser to sign up for junk like this and his terrible performance is not out of character, but Christopher Walken!?!?!? Say it isn't so! It is! He was horrible, the story was horrible, and the script was horrible! Basically their family believes that a nuclear bomb goes off, they climb into a bomb shelter for 35 years, and then come out to find a new world. All attempts at humor fail miserably, skip this movie. If you want a laugh pick up 'Thank You For Smoking' or 'Caddyshack.'

reviews.review_title: Some good performances in search of a little more of a story
reviews.content: This story of a 35-year-old Brendan Fraser raised in a fallout shelter and then has to navigate the world for the first time is cute, but doesn't quite coalesce and lacks the comedic or story punch it should.Fraser's a perfect fish out of water, nice boy from raised from the pretense of '60s suburban life. Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek play his parents and they're fantastic, we spend a lot of the first half of the movie with them and it works well. Alicia Silverstone plays the love interest trying not to fall for Fraser as she helps him gather what he's looking for on the surface world, she's giving the same performance she always does. Dave Foley plays the gay roommate and this was not a bad character, he's played this character on KITH a million times but they wrote the character around some pitfalls so he doesn't feel fully fleshed out, but he's not a total cliche.The movie's got charm, but not enough laughs, and misses some logic to the way the story moves throughout. It's "cute" but feels like it could have been raucously funny or a smarter, better story at nearly every moment.After the halfway mark, the film loses steam until we get to a very forced ending, literally coughed up in the moment to create the dramatic finale, and it doesn't quite work for it.That said, I would absolutely watch a sequel starring Walken, Spacek, and Fraser in those same roles made today.

If you don't expect a masterpiece like 'The Truman Show', you might be in for a pleasant surprise. Christopher Walken and Sissy Spacek are marvellous as parents trapped in a bomb shelter. Brendan Fraser (one of the more irritating young actors, until now) is quite good as their son, thrown into a mutant-infested la-laland (O.K., just 1998 Los Angeles). Alicia Silverstone, as his newfound friend, finally approaches the likeability she displayed in 'Clueless'. The movie is slow moving in spots, but has its funny moments and an overall endearing quality. In all, any movie that chooses Randy Newman's 'Political Science' as the music for its final images can't be all bad. Seven out of ten.

reviews.review_title: A VERY UNDER-RATED AND FUNNY FILM
reviews.content: MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS (I DON'T THINK SO, BUT MIGHT)I cannot get enough of this film.  I saw it in the theatres 3 times, and enjoyed every minute (well, there were a few things I would edit, mostly just some language).I now have this on DVD, and each time I play it for (new) friends, all agree it is very enjoyable.  Even my children, ages 9, 15 and 18, are (unusually) in agreement that this is a good film.  The scenes and music in the fall-out shelter have a very comfortable and, well, 'sheltered' feeling with the music really complimenting the story which then contrasts sharply with the music Adam hears when he "goes up top".Though Silverstone is very pessimistic through most of the film and somewhat irritating, Fraser and Silverstone's gay friend in the film (and Adam's innocent reaction to him) steal the show.  The "fish out of water story" is always, for me, a wonderful way to see things that one normally takes for granted.Highlights for me:  the 'religious experience', the dance club scene, and "remember, it's important that we all remain calm" scene.  Actually scene after scene.You can't lose with this film -- rent it or buy it.

Viewers who accept the premise of this film will probably be tickled by the working out of the comedic complications. Unfortunately, the premise is a non-starter: living in a bomb shelter, no matter how well-appointed, for 35 years is simply not remotely believable. Thus for some of us there isn't anything to latch on to and keep interest engaged. Unless the intention is to parody some genre or some other work, comedy should be based on some reality, however wispy it may be. A premise based only on the merest of wishful thinking is hard-pressed to generate true humor, no matter how clever the writing(this is mildly clever) or charming the performances(pretty charming here).

This movie was a show in for at least 9/10 rating because it told a realistic story while giving it a comedy aspect (Dave Foley).  If you have the time I really recommend watching this at least once especially if you were raised during the 60's and want to see some classic objects or just like comedies.

I went into this movie expecting a 'chick-flick'. I came out laughing my head off. This was definitely one of the funniest movies I've seen in the past year. The acting was excellent and the sets were top-notch. I recommend this film for *any* film-goer.

reviews.review_title: Great Movie. Shows Ignorance is Bliss!
reviews.content:
This film is fantastic, especially living in 2020. I need to be honest. Every time I leave the house, I remind myself to take a second to stop and look around my surroundings, and every single time my brain goes to this movie and the scene were Christopher Walken goes up from the bomb shelter to make sure it's safe for his family and he loses his mind regarding what he sees in 1999!
Ie: People eating out of the trash, people looking like "Mutants", men dressed as women etc... It always creates a small little smeark, and inside my head, I start thinking about that song 'You ain't seen nothin' yet'!
Ba, Ba, Ba Baby you just ain't seen nothing yet! Thinking about the future gives me chills tbh, and makes me enjoy light hearted films like this even more. In times like these.

This is a movie with enough romance to be a chick movie (sorry, no tears though); but enough good laughs for guys to enjoy too.  A sure-fire winner for a date movie.  No sex, minimal profanity, no serious violence.  Just good clean fun.

reviews.review_title: This movie blasts me out of my seat from start to finish, great movie
reviews.content: I love romantic comedies because it requires the audience to do very little thinking. Blast From The Past is the type of movie that people go to and sit in their seat and relax. Blast From The Past's introduction made me smile because it was done with such brilliance. Going in to see this movie, I never did appreciate Brendan Fraser, the actor; however, after his performance in Blast From The Past; I have come to like him. Fraser portrayed his character, Adam Webber, with innocence just as Brad Pitt did in Meet Joe Black. Living in a bomb shelter underground for the first thirty-five years of his life, Adam is in search of a girl as well as supplies for his parents. Alicia Silverstone is gorgeous on and off screen. Alicia Silverstone reminds me of another actress with blonde hair named Drew Barrymore. Silverstone plays a girl aptly named Eve. One of the big cast surprises was Christopher Walken who teamed with Alicia in Excess Baggage. Walken is Calvin Webber, an oddball genious scientist. I love Christopher Walken because he isn't the villan as he is accustomed to in past roles. Blast From The Past kept me smiling from start to finish. This is movie for the whole family to see. I rate this a 9 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: I blame the pacing and chemistry. Not a great script. *partial spoiler*
reviews.content: I love Alicia Silverstone, I own "Excess Baggage", "The Crush", "Scorched", and soon "Batman and Robin" (not because it's good, merely for comedic value, believe me) here was my problem.The movie begins with Adam in the bomb shelter, being born, etc. Basically everything that happens up to 35 years later, they show lots of stuff: Adam learning different languages, learning to box, dancing, lots of stuff. My first suggestion would have been to cut a few minutes off the beginning, I know that sounds nuts but hear me out. There was a lot of stuff that didn't really need to be there, it was about half an hour until Adam finally meets Eve. So we follow this lost puppy without an opposite for a while, it actually is tough to call because a lot of the beginning was necessary, a few minutes less would have made it better. I'm sorry but it really did drag a bit.The second problem, Eve, Alicia is generally a very sweet, quirky, cute girl. In this she was for lack of a better word: a complete bitch. So here we have this guy, trying to find a woman and the character that was written in this instance is offering him nothing but contempt, which is what I found very unsettling considering what this movie was aiming for.She does eventually warm up too him... when the movie is ALMOST over. So let me just recap this for you readers, We spend 30 minutes building up Adam as a character, have about 30 minutes of a character that treats him pretty badly, then we have maybe 15 minutes of sweetening, they remain off screen for another 15 minutes, then it ends. I felt a little ripped off. There were no moments of any closure for this relationship, I'm not joking, if he'd stare at her it would be "STOP STARING AT ME!", yes, it's funny, but it hurts the characters relationship believability.It not being as ROMANTIC as some would like wouldn't have been a problem if the subject matter would have been a little lighter hearted, I mean, we have a family down in a shelter for 35 years, you can't help but feel sorry for this guy. Then he gets harped on for a majority of the movie, then all of a sudden, a REALIZATION of LOVE? I just didn't buy it, the two had only known each other for a couple days... okay... same went for Excess Baggage, but at least with EB we SAW the connections being made earlier than the 80 minute mark, I believed the characters feelings in Excess Baggage, I really did. This one just didn't do it I'm afraid.The points go for some sweet moments, a funny fight scene, Dave Foley was really good and gets 3 points alone, and the soundtrack was pretty cool. Overall, if you really want a light hearted comedy with some really sweet moments,you can't go wrong with Excess Baggage or Scorched. Or this either really, depending on what you're looking for.

reviews.review_title: This movie was the best i have seen in a long time.
reviews.content: Brendan Fraser played such a warm, loving character, that one could not resist liking him. The movie had a great plot, and great actors. (I especially liked Troy) I give this wonderful movie two thumbs way up, and hope that everyone will see it.

This is a cute, albeit forgettable comedy romance about a man who comes out in the real world after living in a nuclear fallout shelter all his life. Strange to see both Alicia Silverstone and Brendon Fraser completely fall off the face of this Earth now but back in 1999 they were as big a stars as one could be. The chemistry is lacking to be honest and the film sort of just plods through though there are some cute moments scattered about. Blast from the Past is a decent watch if there is nothing else to see. Otherwise you're better off renting Clueless or The Mummy.

This is a boring film that lacks everything that makes a good comedy work. I felt sorry for the actors trying desperately to do something - just something - to save this film, but the little they show is ruined by the bad directing and the overall stupidity of the storytelling. The idea of this film could have worked but it seems to me that the filmmakers simply stopped there, hoping it was enough to have an idea and this cast. For me it is not that simple. It reminded me of another bore I saw few years ago, Mrs. Winterbourne. I hope Brendan Fraser doesn't get stuck in these kind of bad movies.

I must admit that reviews for Blast From The Past were not good here, so I was expecting to be disappointed - but exactly the opposite is true. This is truly a good, clean, funny movie. Absolutely charming. Special applause for Mr. Walken's performance as he completely stole the show as the wacky father-from-another-era. The guy's a chameleon. I loved it and will probably go see it again! A+

Honestly this is why Hollywood is in decline. How this movie got green lit is beyond me. Firstly let me start with the plot. It is at best cringe worthy. But this is Hollywood so I guess suspension of disbelief is in order. Further the acting is what makes this movie a real stinker. Really you cant expect much from Brendan. He is pretty much the simple over the hill actor whom at best can capture the camera in some scenes. However Alica is just terrible (as always). Looks aside this girl ruined the movie with her catty talk and worst of all cringe worthy tone. She has no talent aside from looks which is why her career has plummeted. Aside from that the rest of the actors are forgettable at best. Do yourself a favor and skip this stinker. Watch Back to the Future instead or something like that. Or like all of us who have seen this movie you will wish you could blast yourself to the past to erase this movie!

reviews.review_title: This is a feel good movie!
reviews.content: This is a great movie in the old-fashioned tradition of movies being good, clean escapism.Of course you wouldn't want to delve too deeply into the basic idea of a guy being born in a bomb shelter and living there for 35 years, if you do feel you need to do that then you just don't get what going to the cinema is all about.Go and watch this will your kids/friends/partner you'll laugh and come out of the movie feeling just a little bit better about everything.

reviews.review_title: A must see pleasant surprise!!! Very Funny!
reviews.content: "Blast from the Past" is a pleasant surprise!  It is not another one of these teen flicks rolling into theaters like the Chevy Suburban.  Alicia Silverstone is back, still beautiful, but more importantly serious about her career, confident, and terrific on screen.  Brendan Fraser, after his terrific performance in "Gods and Monsters", takes a comedic turn and returns to his roots, and pulls it off nicely.  The supporting cast, including Christopher Walken (not as a villian), is excellent.  Overall a witty movie that doesn't push its point, but rather keeps you entertained!

In agreement with those reviewers who did not fall for this film, I must say that it was too implausible/non-engaging for being truly romantic and far too boring for being a comedy. Christopher Walken and some of the other supporting actors do - admittedly - a very good job on their characters but for the rest ... Apart from the jokes not being particularly funny and the "funny sequences" too overacted/too easily predicted, I really questioned the conservative moral which seemed to be the basis of the exercise: The leading idea seemed to be to hold up Brendan Fraser's character (too overacting to be considered really human, by the way;-)as a kind of positive counterforce to the presumed degenerated manners of present days' people. Surely, I'm not an opponent of politeness etc but this "everything was really better in the good old days"-attitude really did get on my nerves. Rather than to recommend this film to anyone, I would instead suggest watching "Welcome to Pleasantville", which also deals with the issues of "past meets present" but in an overwhelmingly much better, intelligent, funny and emotionally enjoyable way!

reviews.review_title: A LITTLE MORE BLAST AND A LITTLE LESS PAST
reviews.content: Imagine yourself never seeing the light of day.  Being underground thinking that all life is extinct.  Living for 35 years underground WITH CHRISTOPHER WALKEN!!!!!  Well, not surprisingly it leads Adam Webber's dear old mother to heavily drinking.  This was good even after a somewhat slow start.  They spend too much time in the shelter watching him grow up.  Although I can understand why.  I mean you have a talent like Christopher Walken you want to use it.  Some of those scenes work and, overall, do set up the movie well. It just gets it off to a bumpy start.  But after getting past that point the movie sails much smoother.Fraser plays the naive young man who doesn't know anything about our world today.  Fascinated by the sky the ocean and excited to see a Negro.  (his words mine no hate mail please) Silverstone plays the aimless attractive young woman whose relationships have left her in her current jaded state. Fraser's innocents and gentleman charm which is unheard of to the characters of this movie wins her heart.  Fraser discovering this modern world had plenty of funny moments and the rest of the cast helped carry the rest of the movie along.Silverstone was at her best since at least Clueless, maybe her best ever (although I realize that isn't saying much if you're going by movies like Batman).  David Foley was great and had many of the funny moments in this movie.  Some of the scenes did not work like when at the end of the movie it's in slow motion. I see what they were trying but it just didn't work for me.  Other scenes like the cult that had started to worship them did work well although the early scenes that set it up will puzzle you for awhile.  So, overall I say it is worth your money if you're looking for a good comedy. 7.8 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Fun Movie with 50's Nostalgia and Brendan Fraser - what more do you need?
reviews.content: For some reason I never get tired of this movie, I think it is because it has everything: Brendan Fraser, Brendan Fraser and Bredan Frazier. Actually, I like Alicia Silverstone too and this is the first time I can remember seeing Nathan Fillion (who was later to be Captain Mal on the Serenity in the Firefly series).To me, this film has everything: fun, laughs, nostalgia, music, and it is above all a love story. Sissy Spacek is perfect in her role as is Christopher Walker. There are a lot of really great stars in this film and I guess I wish it was not just relegated to just below cult film status. Alas, maybe I should just be happy they made it and I get to see it whenever I need a Brendan Fraser fix. Oh, and, watch Brendan during the beach scene.

This movie is warm and satisfying.  A witty comedy with a brilliant cast, including Brendan Fraser--playing yet another displaced character, "Adam"--and an hilarious Christopher Walken as the father.  Dave Foley is perfect as the gay friend of Alicia Silverstone's "Eve."  This film is a sweet, funny tale and good for the whole family.

reviews.review_title: I wish *I* could live in the Webbers' shelter!
reviews.content: I really enjoyed this movie - bearing in mind that I live in a 50's modern house and and trying to furnish it in period. I want every stick of furniture in the house, especially the turquoise fridge!I have heard disparaging comments on the dancing scene from friends into swing music. It looked EXACTLY like the dancing I see in clubs here all  the time. People DO dance that way. It looked REAL to me, not like Fred Astaire but the way I see people actually dance. Poor footworkand all. But the aerials were dead on...for what I see on the floor in average, everyday, non competition situations.Besides, following the premise, it was the first time he'd danced with anyone besides his mom. Does ANYONE dance perfectly the first time out with a new partner?I've also heard comments from friends about Adam doing swing vs 60's dances...well, I was born in 1965 and MY parents didn't own any "rock and roll" either. They were older - my mom was 30 when I was born - and in fact a lot like Adam's parents. I got the Lettermen, Sinatra, the 4 Lads, the Kingston Trio, Lambert Hendricks and Ross, Tom Lehrer, a tonof Broadway soundtracks and I think one lone Chubby Checker lp from their "when I born" collection. The Twist was a pretty radical modern dance in 62. It was also a "fad" and the subject of much lampooning at the time.A friend of mine said: "Brendan Fraser's clothes were lame again ..."They were SUPPOSED to be. His mom made them from old curtains and bedspreads and recycled other clothes. You COULD say, hey, why didn't they pack more clothes, but when they were outfitting the shelter, Mom never thought they'd need it, and Dad was more concerned with the geeky techno survival aspect to consider wardrobe. He was a GUY, after all, and he was thinking more about the bar and the TV than he was about what he was gonna wear in 30 years. If he had been thinking that, he would have packed a spare pair of glasses, too.Of course, the minute Adam went above ground, he'd have caught adozen different cold and flu viruses, never having been exposed,but that's another whole argument.I still think it's a well-thought out, plausible scenario. And,it IS a comedy, so the science slips a little. But it sure couldhave been a lot more far fetched and silly.It's very well done, amazing attention to detail (especially in the small details of the house), excellent period, well thought out and written and FUNNY!!! Just small things, like how 1998 LA could look like a nuclear holocaust to an uninformed onlooker...priceless.

It tried so hard to be a good film, it really did, it just didn't succeed that's all. Sissy Spacek is in her worst role ever, she seems to be mocking herself sometimes. I've always hated Christipher Walken, he's creepy right? Alicia Silverstone should do porn, I'm pretty sure that's all she'll ever be good at, because she sure as hell can't act. Brenden Frasier saves the show though, his performance is hilarious, he's a very talented guy. Overall this was a disappointing waste of $8 dollars I could've used to see 'Gods And Monsters'.

Okay, I'll admit, the movie was a bit unrealistic.  I don't care how smart the dad is, he isn't going to build something that elaborate, plus, if he's so smart, why couldn't he invent something to test for the radiation levels above the surface.. Come on.  .... but, if you can buy the premise that this really happened, then you have to admit that it was cute movie.  I enjoyed it.  The actors pulled it off quite well.  It did become believable.  I thought it was cute.

reviews.review_title: At last! A movie depicting courtesy as a virtue!
reviews.content: Enjoyable light romantic comedy.Can't say it strongly enough.  This movie depicts a truth that is often lost - the not-so-common-anymore-common-courtesies of past generations can co-exist in the 90's world of personal freedoms.  A refreshing picture.Silverstone, Fraser, Spacek, Walken and Foley were all funny and believable. Spacek had me in stitches.Good movie!!

reviews.review_title: One of the better movies I've seen!
reviews.content: I loved this movie!  Brendan Frasier was very believable as a guy who was innocent to modern society.  Alicia Silverstone was very convincing as Eve, who was a modern, normal, woman of the 90s. But my favorite character was Troy.  I love Dave Foley!  Most of my favorite lines come from his character.  He was also very believable as a gay man.My only real problem about the whole premise was that fact that Eve and Troy wasn't all that curious about Adam.  The only mention that they wonder about him is Troy's comment that he might be from the "X-Files".
